0.author: A. A. Milne
0.quote: Promise me you'll always remember: You're braver than you believe, and stronger than you seem, and smarter than you think.

1.author: A. A. Milne
1.quote: Weeds are flowers too, once you get to know them.

2.author: A. A. Milne
2.quote: It is more fun to talk with someone who doesn't use long, difficult words but rather short, easy words, like 'What about lunch?'

3.author: A. A. Milne
3.quote: Organizing is what you do before you do something, so that when you do it, it is not all mixed up.

4.author: A. A. Milne
4.quote: To the uneducated, an A is just three sticks.

5.author: A. A. Milne
5.quote: You can't stay in your corner of the forest waiting for others to come to you. You have to go to them sometimes.

6.author: A. A. Milne
6.quote: What I say is that, if a fellow really likes potatoes, he must be a pretty decent sort of fellow.

7.author: A. A. Milne
7.quote: The Old Testament is responsible for more atheism, agnosticism, disbelief - call it what you will - than any book ever written. It has emptied more churches than all the counter-attractions of cinema, motor-bicycle and golf course.

8.author: A. A. Milne
8.quote: Did you ever stop to think, and forget to start again?

9.author: A. A. Milne
9.quote: Don't underestimate the value of doing nothing, of just going along, listening to all the thing you can't hear, and not bothering.

10.author: A. A. Milne
10.quote: The third-rate mind is only happy when it is thinking with the majority. The second-rate mind is only happy when it is thinking with the minority. The first-rate mind is only happy when it is thinking.

11.author: A. A. Milne
11.quote: Bores can be divided into two classes; those who have their own particular subject, and those who do not need a subject.

12.author: A. A. Milne
12.quote: If you live to be a hundred, I want to live to be a hundred minus one day so I never have to live without you.

13.author: A. A. Milne
13.quote: A clever conjurer is welcome anywhere, and those of us whose powers of entertainment are limited to the setting of booby-traps or the arranging of apple-pie beds must view with envy the much greater tribute of laughter and applause which is the lot of the prestidigitator with some natural gift for legerdemain.

14.author: A. A. Milne
14.quote: Some people care too much. I think it's called love.

15.author: A. A. Milne
15.quote: Never forget me, because if I thought you would, I'd never leave.

16.author: A. A. Milne
16.quote: War is something of man's own fostering, and if all mankind renounces it, then it is no longer there.

17.author: A. A. Milne
17.quote: I gave up writing children's books. I wanted to escape from them as I had once wanted to escape from 'Punch': as I have always wanted to escape. In vain.

18.author: A. A. Milne
18.quote: If one is to be called a liar, one may as well make an effort to deserve the name.

19.author: A. A. Milne
19.quote: Golf is so popular simply because it is the best game in the world at which to be bad.

20.author: A. A. Milne
20.quote: Is 'The Wind in the Willows' a children's book? Is 'Alice in Wonderland?' Is 'Treasure Island?' These are masterpieces which we read with pleasure as children, but with how much more pleasure when we are grown-up.

21.author: A. A. Milne
21.quote: My spelling is Wobbly. It's good spelling but it Wobbles, and the letters get in the wrong places.

22.author: A. A. Milne
22.quote: One of the advantages of being disorderly is that one is constantly making exciting discoveries.

24.author: A. A. Milne
24.quote: You will be better advised to watch what we do instead of what we say.

25.author: A. A. Milne
25.quote: I am sure of this: that no one can write a book which children will like unless he write it for himself first.

26.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
26.quote: We should not give up and we should not allow the problem to defeat us.

27.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
27.quote: Let us sacrifice our today so that our children can have a better tomorrow.

28.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
28.quote: Teaching is a very noble profession that shapes the character, caliber, and future of an individual. If the people remember me as a good teacher, that will be the biggest honour for me.

29.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
29.quote: If you want to shine like a sun, first burn like a sun.

30.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
30.quote: Never stop fighting until you arrive at your destined place - that is, the unique you. Have an aim in life, continuously acquire knowledge, work hard, and have perseverance to realise the great life.

31.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
31.quote: Science is a beautiful gift to humanity; we should not distort it.

32.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
32.quote: Look at the sky. We are not alone. The whole universe is friendly to us and conspires only to give the best to those who dream and work.

33.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
33.quote: To succeed in your mission, you must have single-minded devotion to your goal.

34.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
34.quote: If a country is to be corruption free and become a nation of beautiful minds, I strongly feel there are three key societal members who can make a difference. They are the father, the mother and the teacher.

35.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
35.quote: You have to dream before your dreams can come true.

36.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
36.quote: If four things are followed - having a great aim, acquiring knowledge, hard work, and perseverance - then anything can be achieved.

37.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
37.quote: The bird is powered by its own life and by its motivation.

38.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
38.quote: Small aim is a crime; have great aim.

39.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
39.quote: Poetry comes from the highest happiness or the deepest sorrow.

40.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
40.quote: Where there is righteousness in the heart, there is beauty in the character. When there is beauty in the character, there is harmony in the home. When there is harmony in the home, there is order in the nation. When there is order in the nation, there is peace in the world.

41.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
41.quote: Excellence is a continuous process and not an accident.

42.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
42.quote: You see, God helps only people who work hard. That principle is very clear.

43.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
43.quote: War is never a lasting solution for any problem.

44.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
44.quote: To become 'unique,' the challenge is to fight the hardest battle which anyone can imagine until you reach your destination.

45.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
45.quote: Great teachers emanate out of knowledge, passion and compassion.

46.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
46.quote: India should walk on her own shadow - we must have our own development model.

47.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
47.quote: Life is a difficult game. You can win it only by retaining your birthright to be a person.

48.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
48.quote: The youth need to be enabled to become job generators from job seekers.

49.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
49.quote: Great dreams of great dreamers are always transcended.

50.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
50.quote: Man needs his difficulties because they are necessary to enjoy success.

51.author: A. P. J. Abdul Kalam
51.quote: When we tackle obstacles, we find hidden reserves of courage and resilience we did not know we had. And it is only when we are faced with failure do we realise that these resources were always there within us. We only need to find them and move on with our lives.

52.author: Abraham Lincoln
52.quote: All that I am, or hope to be, I owe to my angel mother.

53.author: Abraham Lincoln
53.quote: Nearly all men can stand adversity, but if you want to test a man's character, give him power.

54.author: Abraham Lincoln
54.quote: You cannot escape the responsibility of tomorrow by evading it today.

55.author: Abraham Lincoln
55.quote: I am a slow walker, but I never walk back.

56.author: Abraham Lincoln
56.quote: Be sure you put your feet in the right place, then stand firm.

57.author: Abraham Lincoln
57.quote: No man has a good enough memory to be a successful liar.

58.author: Abraham Lincoln
58.quote: My dream is of a place and a time where America will once again be seen as the last best hope of earth.

59.author: Abraham Lincoln
59.quote: America will never be destroyed from the outside. If we falter and lose our freedoms, it will be because we destroyed ourselves.

60.author: Abraham Lincoln
60.quote: I remember my mother's prayers and they have always followed me. They have clung to me all my life.

61.author: Abraham Lincoln
61.quote: Character is like a tree and reputation like a shadow. The shadow is what we think of it; the tree is the real thing.

62.author: Abraham Lincoln
62.quote: Give me six hours to chop down a tree and I will spend the first four sharpening the axe.

63.author: Abraham Lincoln
63.quote: If this is coffee, please bring me some tea; but if this is tea, please bring me some coffee.

64.author: Abraham Lincoln
64.quote: The ballot is stronger than the bullet.

65.author: Abraham Lincoln
65.quote: I am not bound to win, but I am bound to be true. I am not bound to succeed, but I am bound to live by the light that I have. I must stand with anybody that stands right, and stand with him while he is right, and part with him when he goes wrong.

66.author: Abraham Lincoln
66.quote: Don't worry when you are not recognized, but strive to be worthy of recognition.

67.author: Abraham Lincoln
67.quote: Do I not destroy my enemies when I make them my friends?

68.author: Abraham Lincoln
68.quote: A house divided against itself cannot stand.

69.author: Abraham Lincoln
69.quote: I will prepare and some day my chance will come.

70.author: Abraham Lincoln
70.quote: Whatever you are, be a good one.

71.author: Abraham Lincoln
71.quote: Government of the people, by the people, for the people, shall not perish from the Earth.

72.author: Abraham Lincoln
72.quote: Always bear in mind that your own resolution to succeed is more important than any other.

73.author: Abraham Lincoln
73.quote: You can fool all the people some of the time, and some of the people all the time, but you cannot fool all the people all the time.

74.author: Abraham Lincoln
74.quote: When I do good I feel good, when I do bad I feel bad, and that's my religion.

75.author: Abraham Lincoln
75.quote: We the people are the rightful masters of both Congress and the courts, not to overthrow the Constitution but to overthrow the men who pervert the Constitution.

76.author: Abraham Lincoln
76.quote: My great concern is not whether you have failed, but whether you are content with your failure.

77.author: Abraham Lincoln
77.quote: I do the very best I know how - the very best I can; and I mean to keep on doing so until the end.

78.author: Abraham Maslow
78.quote: If you only have a hammer, you tend to see every problem as a nail.

79.author: Abraham Maslow
79.quote: What is necessary to change a person is to change his awareness of himself.

80.author: Abraham Maslow
80.quote: With a tree, all the growth takes place at the growing tips. Humanity is exactly the same. All the growth takes place in the growing tip: among that one percent of the population. It's made up of pioneers, the beginners. That's where the action is.

81.author: Abraham Maslow
81.quote: The ability to be in the present moment is a major component of mental wellness.

82.author: Abraham Maslow
82.quote: The fact is that people are good, Give people affection and security, and they will give affection and be secure in their feelings and their behavior.

83.author: Abraham Maslow
83.quote: If you plan on being anything less than you are capable of being, you will probably be unhappy all the days of your life.

84.author: Abraham Maslow
84.quote: The science of psychology has been far more successful on the negative than on the positive side... It has revealed to us much about man's shortcomings, his illnesses, his sins, but little about his potentialities, his virtues, his achievable aspirations, or his psychological health.

85.author: Abraham Maslow
85.quote: Being a full human being is difficult, frightening, and problematical.

86.author: Abraham Maslow
86.quote: All the evidence that we have indicates that it is reasonable to assume in practically every human being, and certainly in almost every newborn baby, that there is an active will toward health, an impulse towards growth, or towards the actualization.

87.author: Abraham Maslow
87.quote: What a man can be, he must be. This need we call self-actualization.

88.author: Abraham Maslow
88.quote: Human nature is not nearly as bad as it has been thought to be.

89.author: Abraham Maslow
89.quote: Rioting is a childish way of trying to be a man, but it takes time to rise out of the hell of hatred and frustration and accept that to be a man you don't have to riot.

90.author: Abraham Maslow
90.quote: We fear to know the fearsome and unsavory aspects of ourselves, but we fear even more to know the godlike in ourselves.

91.author: Abraham Maslow
91.quote: If I were a Negro, I'd be fighting, as Martin Luther King fought, for human recognition and justice. I'd rather go down with my flag flying. If you're weak or crippled, or you can't speak out or fight back in some way, then people don't hesitate to treat you badly.

92.author: Abraham Maslow
92.quote: A musician must make music, an artist must paint, a poet must write, if he is to be ultimately at peace with himself.

93.author: Abraham Maslow
93.quote: Education can become a self-fulfilling activity, liberating in and of itself.

94.author: Abraham Maslow
94.quote: The story of the human race is the story of men and women selling themselves short.

95.author: Abraham Maslow
95.quote: I was awfully curious to find out why I didn't go insane.

96.author: Abraham Maslow
96.quote: If you think only of evil, then you become pessimistic and hopeless like Freud. But if you think there is no evil, then you're just one more deluded Pollyanna.

97.author: Abraham Maslow
97.quote: One's only rival is one's own potentialities. One's only failure is failing to live up to one's own possibilities. In this sense, every man can be a king, and must therefore be treated like a king.

98.author: Abraham Maslow
98.quote: Marriage is a school itself. Also, having children. Becoming a father changed my whole life. It taught me as if by revelation.

99.author: Abraham Maslow
99.quote: Dispassionate objectivity is itself a passion, for the real and for the truth.

100.author: Abraham Maslow
100.quote: Classic economic theory, based as it is on an inadequate theory of human motivation, could be revolutionized by accepting the reality of higher human needs, including the impulse to self actualization and the love for the highest values.

101.author: Abraham Maslow
101.quote: I'm someone who likes plowing new ground, then walking away from it. I get bored easily. For me, the big thrill comes with the discovering.

102.author: Abraham Maslow
102.quote: With my childhood, it's a wonder I'm not psychotic. I was the little Jewish boy in the non-Jewish neighborhood. It was a little like being the first Negro enrolled in the all-white school. I grew up in libraries and among books, without friends.

103.author: Abraham Maslow
103.quote: But behavior in the human being is sometimes a defense, a way of concealing motives and thoughts, as language can be a way of hiding your thoughts and preventing communication.

104.author: Adam Smith
104.quote: Science is the great antidote to the poison of enthusiasm and superstition.

105.author: Adam Smith
105.quote: All money is a matter of belief.

106.author: Adam Smith
106.quote: The real tragedy of the poor is the poverty of their aspirations.

107.author: Adam Smith
107.quote: It is not from the benevolence of the butcher, the brewer, or the baker that we expect our dinner, but from their regard to their own interest.

108.author: Adam Smith
108.quote: No society can surely be flourishing and happy, of which the far greater part of the members are poor and miserable.

109.author: Adam Smith
109.quote: Consumption is the sole end and purpose of all production; and the interest of the producer ought to be attended to, only so far as it may be necessary for promoting that of the consumer.

110.author: Adam Smith
110.quote: Man is an animal that makes bargains: no other animal does this - no dog exchanges bones with another.

111.author: Adam Smith
111.quote: Happiness never lays its finger on its pulse.

112.author: Adam Smith
112.quote: Labour was the first price, the original purchase - money that was paid for all things. It was not by gold or by silver, but by labour, that all wealth of the world was originally purchased.

113.author: Adam Smith
113.quote: To feel much for others and little for ourselves; to restrain our selfishness and exercise our benevolent affections, constitute the perfection of human nature.

114.author: Adam Smith
114.quote: I have never known much good done by those who affected to trade for the public good.

115.author: Adam Smith
115.quote: Humanity is the virtue of a woman, generosity that of a man.

116.author: Adam Smith
116.quote: Little else is requisite to carry a state to the highest degree of opulence from the lowest barbarism but peace, easy taxes, and a tolerable administration of justice: all the rest being brought about by the natural course of things.

117.author: Adam Smith
117.quote: It is not by augmenting the capital of the country, but by rendering a greater part of that capital active and productive than would otherwise be so, that the most judicious operations of banking can increase the industry of the country.

118.author: Adam Smith
118.quote: This is one of those cases in which the imagination is baffled by the facts.

119.author: Adam Smith
119.quote: As soon as the land of any country has all become private property, the landlords, like all other men, love to reap where they never sowed, and demand a rent even for its natural produce.

120.author: Adam Smith
120.quote: On the road from the City of Skepticism, I had to pass through the Valley of Ambiguity.

121.author: Adam Smith
121.quote: No complaint... is more common than that of a scarcity of money.

123.author: Adam Smith
123.quote: With the greater part of rich people, the chief enjoyment of riches consists in the parade of riches.

124.author: Adam Smith
124.quote: What can be added to the happiness of a man who is in health, out of debt, and has a clear conscience?

125.author: Adam Smith
125.quote: The propensity to truck, barter and exchange one thing for another is common to all men, and to be found in no other race of animals.

126.author: Adam Smith
126.quote: Virtue is more to be feared than vice, because its excesses are not subject to the regulation of conscience.

127.author: Adam Smith
127.quote: Great ambition, the desire of real superiority, of leading and directing, seems to be altogether peculiar to man, and speech is the great instrument of ambition.

128.author: Adam Smith
128.quote: The theory that can absorb the greatest number of facts, and persist in doing so, generation after generation, through all changes of opinion and detail, is the one that must rule all observation.

129.author: Adam Smith
129.quote: The real and effectual discipline which is exercised over a workman is that of his customers. It is the fear of losing their employment which restrains his frauds and corrects his negligence.

130.author: Aeschylus
130.quote: There is no pain so great as the memory of joy in present grief.

131.author: Aeschylus
131.quote: He who learns must suffer. And even in our sleep pain that cannot forget falls drop by drop upon the heart, and in our own despair, against our will, comes wisdom to us by the awful grace of God.

132.author: Aeschylus
132.quote: Obedience is the mother of success and is wedded to safety.

133.author: Aeschylus
133.quote: There is no sickness worse for me than words that to be kind must lie.

134.author: Aeschylus
134.quote: From a small seed a mighty trunk may grow.

135.author: Aeschylus
135.quote: Memory is the mother of all wisdom.

136.author: Aeschylus
136.quote: God always strives together with those who strive.

137.author: Aeschylus
137.quote: Everyone's quick to blame the alien.

138.author: Aeschylus
138.quote: It is not the oath that makes us believe the man, but the man the oath.

139.author: Aeschylus
139.quote: I have learned to hate all traitors, and there is no disease that I spit on more than treachery.

140.author: Aeschylus
140.quote: What is there more kindly than the feeling between host and guest?

141.author: Aeschylus
141.quote: God lends a helping hand to the man who tries hard.

142.author: Aeschylus
142.quote: In the lack of judgment great harm arises, but one vote cast can set right a house.

143.author: Aeschylus
143.quote: For know that no one is free, except Zeus.

144.author: Aeschylus
144.quote: But time growing old teaches all things.

145.author: Aeschylus
145.quote: You have been trapped in the inescapable net of ruin by your own want of sense.

146.author: Aeschylus
146.quote: My friends, whoever has had experience of evils knows how whenever a flood of ills comes upon mortals, a man fears everything; but whenever a divine force cheers on our voyage, then we believe that the same fate will always blow fair.

148.author: Aeschylus
148.quote: Words are the physicians of a mind diseased.

149.author: Aeschylus
149.quote: Neither a life of anarchy nor one beneath a despot should you praise; to all that lies in the middle a god has given excellence.

150.author: Aeschylus
150.quote: Bronze in the mirror of the form, wine of the mind.

151.author: Aeschylus
151.quote: For the poison of hatred seated near the heart doubles the burden for the one who suffers the disease; he is burdened with his own sorrow, and groans on seeing another's happiness.

152.author: Aeschylus
152.quote: Be bold and boast, just like the cock beside the hen.

153.author: Aeschylus
153.quote: For somehow this disease inheres in tyranny, never to trust one's friends.

154.author: Aeschylus
154.quote: There are times when fear is good. It must keep its watchful place at the heart's controls.

155.author: Aeschylus
155.quote: For children preserve the fame of a man after his death.

156.author: Aesop
156.quote: No act of kindness, no matter how small, is ever wasted.

157.author: Aesop
157.quote: Gratitude is the sign of noble souls.

158.author: Aesop
158.quote: A liar will not be believed, even when he speaks the truth.

159.author: Aesop
159.quote: The level of our success is limited only by our imagination and no act of kindness, however small, is ever wasted.

160.author: Aesop
160.quote: It is not only fine feathers that make fine birds.

161.author: Aesop
161.quote: We hang the petty thieves and appoint the great ones to public office.

162.author: Aesop
162.quote: It is easy to be brave from a safe distance.

163.author: Aesop
163.quote: A crust eaten in peace is better than a banquet partaken in anxiety.

164.author: Aesop
164.quote: Persuasion is often more effectual than force.

165.author: Aesop
165.quote: Injuries may be forgiven, but not forgotten.

166.author: Aesop
166.quote: United we stand, divided we fall.

168.author: Aesop
168.quote: Destroy the seed of evil, or it will grow up to your ruin.

169.author: Aesop
169.quote: Every truth has two sides; it is as well to look at both, before we commit ourselves to either.

170.author: Aesop
170.quote: The unhappy derive comfort from the misfortunes of others.

171.author: Aesop
171.quote: The little reed, bending to the force of the wind, soon stood upright again when the storm had passed over.

173.author: Aesop
173.quote: We should look to the mind, and not to the outward appearance.

174.author: Aesop
174.quote: After all is said and done, more is said than done.

175.author: Aesop
175.quote: Do not count your chickens before they are hatched.

176.author: Aesop
176.quote: Slow but steady wins the race.

177.author: Aesop
177.quote: Affairs are easier of entrance than of exit; and it is but common prudence to see our way out before we venture in.

178.author: Aesop
178.quote: Beware that you do not lose the substance by grasping at the shadow.

179.author: Aesop
179.quote: Please all, and you will please none.

180.author: Aesop
180.quote: He that always gives way to others will end in having no principles of his own.

182.author: Agatha Christie
182.quote: One of the luckiest things that can happen to you in life is, I think, to have a happy childhood.

183.author: Agatha Christie
183.quote: But surely for everything you have to love you have to pay some price.

184.author: Agatha Christie
184.quote: Good advice is always certain to be ignored, but that's no reason not to give it.

185.author: Agatha Christie
185.quote: One doesn't recognize the really important moments in one's life until it's too late.

186.author: Agatha Christie
186.quote: Every murderer is probably somebody's old friend.

187.author: Agatha Christie
187.quote: The happy people are failures because they are on such good terms with themselves they don't give a damn.

188.author: Agatha Christie
188.quote: I like living. I have sometimes been wildly, despairingly, acutely miserable, racked with sorrow, but through it all I still know quite certainly that just to be alive is a grand thing.

189.author: Agatha Christie
189.quote: Crime is terribly revealing. Try and vary your methods as you will, your tastes, your habits, your attitude of mind, and your soul is revealed by your actions.

190.author: Agatha Christie
190.quote: Never do anything yourself that others can do for you.

191.author: Agatha Christie
191.quote: Curious things, habits. People themselves never knew they had them.

192.author: Agatha Christie
192.quote: There is nothing more thrilling in this world, I think, than having a child that is yours, and yet is mysteriously a stranger.

193.author: Agatha Christie
193.quote: If one sticks too rigidly to one's principles, one would hardly see anybody.

194.author: Agatha Christie
194.quote: Everything that has existed, lingers in the Eternity.

195.author: Agatha Christie
195.quote: These little grey cells. It is up to them.

196.author: Agatha Christie
196.quote: I married an archaeologist because the older I grow, the more he appreciates me.

197.author: Agatha Christie
197.quote: Any woman can fool a man if she wants to and if he's in love with her.

198.author: Agatha Christie
198.quote: Most successes are unhappy. That's why they are successes - they have to reassure themselves about themselves by achieving something that the world will notice.

199.author: Agatha Christie
199.quote: An archaeologist is the best husband a woman can have. The older she gets the more interested he is in her.

200.author: Agatha Christie
200.quote: Very few of us are what we seem.

201.author: Agatha Christie
201.quote: The popular idea that a child forgets easily is not an accurate one. Many people go right through life in the grip of an idea which has been impressed on them in very tender years.

202.author: Agatha Christie
202.quote: It is a curious thought, but it is only when you see people looking ridiculous that you realize just how much you love them.

203.author: Agatha Christie
203.quote: There's too much tendency to attribute to God the evils that man does of his own free will.

204.author: Agatha Christie
204.quote: I live now on borrowed time, waiting in the anteroom for the summons that will inevitably come. And then - I go on to the next thing, whatever it is. One doesn't, luckily, have to bother about that.

205.author: Agatha Christie
205.quote: Dogs are wise. They crawl away into a quiet corner and lick their wounds and do not rejoin the world until they are whole once more.

206.author: Agatha Christie
206.quote: I specialize in murders of quiet, domestic interest.

207.author: Agatha Christie
207.quote: Too much mercy... often resulted in further crimes which were fatal to innocent victims who need not have been victims if justice had been put first and mercy second.

208.author: Alan Shepard
208.quote: It's a very sobering feeling to be up in space and realize that one's safety factor was determined by the lowest bidder on a government contract.

209.author: Alan Shepard
209.quote: They say any landing you can walk away from is a good one.

210.author: Alan Shepard
210.quote: You may not have any extra talent, but maybe you are just paying more attention to what you are doing.

211.author: Alan Shepard
211.quote: Of course, in our grade school, in those days, there were no organized sports at all. We just went out and ran around the school yard for recess.

212.author: Alan Shepard
212.quote: The pilot looked at his cues of attitude and speed and orientation and so on and responded as he would from the same cues in an airplane, but there was no way it flew the same. The simulators had showed us that.

213.author: Alan Shepard
213.quote: You know, being a test pilot isn't always the healthiest business in the world.

214.author: Alan Shepard
214.quote: I must admit, maybe I am a piece of history after all.

215.author: Alan Shepard
215.quote: Whether you are an astronomer or a life scientist, geophysicist, or a pilot, you've got to be there because you believe you are good in your field, and you can contribute, not because you are going to get a lot of fame or whatever when you get back.

216.author: Alan Shepard
216.quote: So everything turned out fine, and we were given the opportunity to go to Washington and be briefed on the project of man in space, and given the opportunity to choose whether we wanted to get involved or not.

217.author: Alan Shepard
217.quote: I'd like to say I was smart enough to finish six grades in five years, but I think perhaps the teacher was just glad to get rid of me.

218.author: Alan Shepard
218.quote: It's been a long way, but we're here.

219.author: Alan Shepard
219.quote: And I think that still is true of this business - which is basically research and development - that you probably spend more time in planning and training and designing for things to go wrong, and how you cope with them, than you do for things to go right.

220.author: Alan Shepard
220.quote: We wanted to be in great shape, we wanted to be able to cope with zero gravity, we wanted to be able to cope with accelerations and decelerations and so on. So all of us trained so that we were probably in the best physical condition we had ever been in up until that point.

221.author: Alan Shepard
221.quote: But when I was selected, after my very first tour of squadron duty, to become one of the youngest candidates for the test pilot school, I began to realize, maybe you are a little bit better.

222.author: Alan Shepard
222.quote: Later, in the early teens, I used to ride my bike every Saturday morning to the nearest airport, ten miles away, push airplanes in and out of the hangars, and clean up the hangars.

223.author: Alan Shepard
223.quote: You have to be there not for the fame and glory and recognition and being a page in a history book, but you have to be there because you believe your talent and ability can be applied effectively to operation of the spacecraft.

224.author: Alan Shepard
224.quote: I didn't mind studying. Obviously math and the physical science subjects interested me more than some of the more artistic subjects, but I think I was a pretty good student.

225.author: Alan Shepard
225.quote: I think all of us certainly believed the statistics which said that probably 88% chance of mission success and maybe 96% chance of survival. And we were willing to take those odds.

226.author: Alan Shepard
226.quote: I think the sense of family and family achievement, plus the discipline which I received there from that one-room school were really very helpful in what I did later on.

227.author: Alan Shepard
227.quote: I woke up an hour before I was supposed to, and started going over the mental checklist: where do I go from here, what do I do? I don't remember eating anything at all, just going through the physical, getting into the suit. We practiced that so much, it was all rote.

228.author: Alan Shepard
228.quote: Obviously I was challenged by becoming a Naval aviator, by landing aboard aircraft carriers and so on.

229.author: Alan Shepard
229.quote: Of course I was delighted the flight was over, but I still had to worry about cleaning up inside the cabin, I had to worry about the hatch, how to get in the sling, and so on.

230.author: Alan Shepard
230.quote: The excitement really didn't start to build until the trailer - which was carrying me, with a space suit with ventilation and all that sort of stuff - pulled up to the launch pad.

231.author: Alan Shepard
231.quote: The first plane ride was in a homemade glider my buddy and I built. Unfortunately we didn't get more than four feet off the ground, because it crashed.

232.author: Alan Shepard
232.quote: The rocket had worked perfectly, and all I had to do was survive the reentry forces. You do it all, in a flight like that, in a rather short period of time, just 16 minutes as a matter of fact.

233.author: Alan Shepard
233.quote: Then there was the challenge to keep doing better and better, to fly the best test flight that anybody had ever flown. That led to my being recognized as one of the more experienced test pilots, and that led to the astronaut business.

234.author: Alan Watts
234.quote: The only way to make sense out of change is to plunge into it, move with it, and join the dance.

235.author: Alan Watts
235.quote: To have faith is to trust yourself to the water. When you swim you don't grab hold of the water, because if you do you will sink and drown. Instead you relax, and float.

236.author: Alan Watts
236.quote: We cannot be more sensitive to pleasure without being more sensitive to pain.

237.author: Alan Watts
237.quote: The ego is nothing other than the focus of conscious attention.

238.author: Alan Watts
238.quote: But I'll tell you what hermits realize. If you go off into a far, far forest and get very quiet, you'll come to understand that you're connected with everything.

239.author: Alan Watts
239.quote: So then, the relationship of self to other is the complete realization that loving yourself is impossible without loving everything defined as other than yourself.

240.author: Alan Watts
240.quote: I have realized that the past and future are real illusions, that they exist in the present, which is what there is and all there is.

241.author: Alan Watts
241.quote: Reality is only a Rorschach ink-blot, you know.

242.author: Alan Watts
242.quote: No work or love will flourish out of guilt, fear, or hollowness of heart, just as no valid plans for the future can be made by those who have no capacity for living now.

243.author: Alan Watts
243.quote: Never pretend to a love which you do not actually feel, for love is not ours to command.

244.author: Alan Watts
244.quote: No valid plans for the future can be made by those who have no capacity for living now.

246.author: Alan Watts
246.quote: But the attitude of faith is to let go, and become open to truth, whatever it might turn out to be.

247.author: Alan Watts
247.quote: You don't look out there for God, something in the sky, you look in you.

248.author: Alan Watts
248.quote: Trying to define yourself is like trying to bite your own teeth.

249.author: Alan Watts
249.quote: You and I are all as much continuous with the physical universe as a wave is continuous with the ocean.

250.author: Alan Watts
250.quote: You are that vast thing that you see far, far off with great telescopes.

251.author: Alan Watts
251.quote: In other words, a person who is fanatic in matters of religion, and clings to certain ideas about the nature of God and the universe, becomes a person who has no faith at all.

252.author: Alan Watts
252.quote: The reason we want to go on and on is because we live in an impoverished present.

253.author: Alan Watts
253.quote: A myth is an image in terms of which we try to make sense of the world.

254.author: Alan Watts
254.quote: Technology is destructive only in the hands of people who do not realize that they are one and the same process as the universe.

255.author: Alan Watts
255.quote: And the attitude of faith is the very opposite of clinging to belief, of holding on.

256.author: Alan Watts
256.quote: The style of God venerated in the church, mosque, or synagogue seems completely different from the style of the natural universe.

257.author: Alan Watts
257.quote: I owe my solitude to other people.

258.author: Alan Watts
258.quote: Things are as they are. Looking out into it the universe at night, we make no comparisons between right and wrong stars, nor between well and badly arranged constellations.

259.author: Alan Watts
259.quote: The myths underlying our culture and underlying our common sense have not taught us to feel identical with the universe, but only parts of it, only in it, only confronting it - aliens.

260.author: Albert Camus
260.quote: Autumn is a second spring when every leaf is a flower.

261.author: Albert Camus
261.quote: Freedom is nothing but a chance to be better.

262.author: Albert Camus
262.quote: In the depth of winter I finally learned that there was in me an invincible summer.

263.author: Albert Camus
263.quote: Don't walk behind me; I may not lead. Don't walk in front of me; I may not follow. Just walk beside me and be my friend.

264.author: Albert Camus
264.quote: A man without ethics is a wild beast loosed upon this world.

265.author: Albert Camus
265.quote: Blessed are the hearts that can bend; they shall never be broken.

266.author: Albert Camus
266.quote: Real generosity toward the future lies in giving all to the present.

267.author: Albert Camus
267.quote: You will never be happy if you continue to search for what happiness consists of. You will never live if you are looking for the meaning of life.

268.author: Albert Camus
268.quote: The only way to deal with an unfree world is to become so absolutely free that your very existence is an act of rebellion.

269.author: Albert Camus
269.quote: Basically, at the very bottom of life, which seduces us all, there is only absurdity, and more absurdity. And maybe that's what gives us our joy for living, because the only thing that can defeat absurdity is lucidity.

270.author: Albert Camus
270.quote: In order to exist, man must rebel, but rebellion must respect the limits that it discovers in itself - limits where minds meet, and in meeting, begin to exist.

271.author: Albert Camus
271.quote: Integrity has no need of rules.

272.author: Albert Camus
272.quote: To be happy we must not be too concerned with others.

273.author: Albert Camus
273.quote: An intellectual is someone whose mind watches itself.

274.author: Albert Camus
274.quote: A guilty conscience needs to confess. A work of art is a confession.

275.author: Albert Camus
275.quote: As a remedy to life in society I would suggest the big city. Nowadays, it is the only desert within our means.

276.author: Albert Camus
276.quote: I would rather live my life as if there is a God and die to find out there isn't, than live as if there isn't and to die to find out that there is.

277.author: Albert Camus
277.quote: A free press can, of course, be good or bad, but, most certainly without freedom, the press will never be anything but bad.

278.author: Albert Camus
278.quote: Nothing is more despicable than respect based on fear.

279.author: Albert Camus
279.quote: Those who lack the courage will always find a philosophy to justify it.

280.author: Albert Camus
280.quote: Men must live and create. Live to the point of tears.

281.author: Albert Camus
281.quote: What is a rebel? A man who says no: but whose refusal does not imply a renunciation.

282.author: Albert Camus
282.quote: At any street corner the feeling of absurdity can strike any man in the face.

283.author: Albert Camus
283.quote: Truth, like light, blinds. Falsehood, on the contrary, is a beautiful twilight that enhances every object.

284.author: Albert Camus
284.quote: Too many have dispensed with generosity in order to practice charity.

285.author: Albert Camus
285.quote: You cannot create experience. You must undergo it.

286.author: Albert Einstein
286.quote: Look deep into nature, and then you will understand everything better.

287.author: Albert Einstein
287.quote: Life is like riding a bicycle. To keep your balance, you must keep moving.

288.author: Albert Einstein
288.quote: Education is what remains after one has forgotten what one has learned in school.

289.author: Albert Einstein
289.quote: I have no special talent. I am only passionately curious.

290.author: Albert Einstein
290.quote: The true sign of intelligence is not knowledge but imagination.

291.author: Albert Einstein
291.quote: Try not to become a man of success, but rather try to become a man of value.

292.author: Albert Einstein
292.quote: Weakness of attitude becomes weakness of character.

293.author: Albert Einstein
293.quote: The difference between stupidity and genius is that genius has its limits.

294.author: Albert Einstein
294.quote: Pure mathematics is, in its way, the poetry of logical ideas.

295.author: Albert Einstein
295.quote: We cannot solve our problems with the same thinking we used when we created them.

296.author: Albert Einstein
296.quote: Science without religion is lame, religion without science is blind.

297.author: Albert Einstein
297.quote: Whoever is careless with the truth in small matters cannot be trusted with important matters.

298.author: Albert Einstein
298.quote: The only source of knowledge is experience.

299.author: Albert Einstein
299.quote: Learn from yesterday, live for today, hope for tomorrow. The important thing is not to stop questioning.

300.author: Albert Einstein
300.quote: Logic will get you from A to B. Imagination will take you everywhere.

301.author: Albert Einstein
301.quote: Nationalism is an infantile disease. It is the measles of mankind.

302.author: Albert Einstein
302.quote: Anyone who has never made a mistake has never tried anything new.

303.author: Albert Einstein
303.quote: It is the supreme art of the teacher to awaken joy in creative expression and knowledge.

304.author: Albert Einstein
304.quote: Only two things are infinite, the universe and human stupidity, and I'm not sure about the former.

305.author: Albert Einstein
305.quote: Do not worry about your difficulties in Mathematics. I can assure you mine are still greater.

306.author: Albert Einstein
306.quote: Once we accept our limits, we go beyond them.

307.author: Albert Einstein
307.quote: Peace cannot be kept by force; it can only be achieved by understanding.

308.author: Albert Einstein
308.quote: It's not that I'm so smart, it's just that I stay with problems longer.

309.author: Albert Einstein
309.quote: I live in that solitude which is painful in youth, but delicious in the years of maturity.

310.author: Albert Einstein
310.quote: The important thing is not to stop questioning. Curiosity has its own reason for existing.

311.author: Albert Einstein
311.quote: Any man who reads too much and uses his own brain too little falls into lazy habits of thinking.

312.author: Albert Schweitzer
312.quote: The purpose of human life is to serve, and to show compassion and the will to help others.

313.author: Albert Schweitzer
313.quote: In everyone's life, at some time, our inner fire goes out. It is then burst into flame by an encounter with another human being. We should all be thankful for those people who rekindle the inner spirit.

314.author: Albert Schweitzer
314.quote: At times our own light goes out and is rekindled by a spark from another person. Each of us has cause to think with deep gratitude of those who have lighted the flame within us.

315.author: Albert Schweitzer
315.quote: Happiness is nothing more than good health and a bad memory.

316.author: Albert Schweitzer
316.quote: Never say there is nothing beautiful in the world anymore. There is always something to make you wonder in the shape of a tree, the trembling of a leaf.

317.author: Albert Schweitzer
317.quote: There are two means of refuge from the miseries of life: music and cats.

318.author: Albert Schweitzer
318.quote: Do something wonderful, people may imitate it.

319.author: Albert Schweitzer
319.quote: Sometimes our light goes out but is blown into flame by another human being. Each of us owes deepest thanks to those who have rekindled this light.

320.author: Albert Schweitzer
320.quote: One who gains strength by overcoming obstacles possesses the only strength which can overcome adversity.

321.author: Albert Schweitzer
321.quote: The first step in the evolution of ethics is a sense of solidarity with other human beings.

322.author: Albert Schweitzer
322.quote: Constant kindness can accomplish much. As the sun makes ice melt, kindness causes misunderstanding, mistrust, and hostility to evaporate.

323.author: Albert Schweitzer
323.quote: Success is not the key to happiness. Happiness is the key to success. If you love what you are doing, you will be successful.

324.author: Albert Schweitzer
324.quote: We are all so much together, but we are all dying of loneliness.

325.author: Albert Schweitzer
325.quote: An optimist is a person who sees a green light everywhere, while a pessimist sees only the red stoplight... the truly wise person is colorblind.

326.author: Albert Schweitzer
326.quote: Do not let Sunday be taken from you. If your soul has no Sunday, it becomes an orphan.

327.author: Albert Schweitzer
327.quote: Ethics is the activity of man directed to secure the inner perfection of his own personality.

328.author: Albert Schweitzer
328.quote: The tragedy of life is what dies inside a man while he lives.

329.author: Albert Schweitzer
329.quote: Man can hardly even recognize the devils of his own creation.

330.author: Albert Schweitzer
330.quote: A man does not have to be an angel in order to be saint.

331.author: Albert Schweitzer
331.quote: Man is a clever animal who behaves like an imbecile.

332.author: Albert Schweitzer
332.quote: By having a reverence for life, we enter into a spiritual relation with the world By practicing reverence for life we become good, deep, and alive.

333.author: Albert Schweitzer
333.quote: One thing I know: the only ones among you who will be really happy are those who will have sought and found how to serve.

334.author: Albert Schweitzer
334.quote: If a man loses his reverence for any part of life, he will lose his reverence for all of life.

335.author: Albert Schweitzer
335.quote: Do something for somebody everyday for which you do not get paid.

336.author: Albert Schweitzer
336.quote: Humanitarianism consists in never sacrificing a human being to a purpose.

337.author: Albert Schweitzer
337.quote: Ethics is nothing else than reverence for life.

338.author: Aldous Huxley
338.quote: There is only one corner of the universe you can be certain of improving, and that's your own self.

339.author: Aldous Huxley
339.quote: There are things known and there are things unknown, and in between are the doors of perception.

340.author: Aldous Huxley
340.quote: The secret of genius is to carry the spirit of the child into old age, which means never losing your enthusiasm.

341.author: Aldous Huxley
341.quote: After silence, that which comes nearest to expressing the inexpressible is music.

342.author: Aldous Huxley
342.quote: Experience is not what happens to you; it's what you do with what happens to you.

344.author: Aldous Huxley
344.quote: You shall know the truth, and the truth shall make you mad.

345.author: Aldous Huxley
345.quote: Facts do not cease to exist because they are ignored.

346.author: Aldous Huxley
346.quote: Technological progress has merely provided us with more efficient means for going backwards.

347.author: Aldous Huxley
347.quote: Maybe this world is another planet's hell.

348.author: Aldous Huxley
348.quote: The worst enemy of life, freedom and the common decencies is total anarchy; their second worst enemy is total efficiency.

349.author: Aldous Huxley
349.quote: Everyone who wants to do good to the human race always ends in universal bullying.

350.author: Aldous Huxley
350.quote: My fate cannot be mastered; it can only be collaborated with and thereby, to some extent, directed. Nor am I the captain of my soul; I am only its noisiest passenger.

351.author: Aldous Huxley
351.quote: God isn't compatible with machinery and scientific medicine and universal happiness. You must make your choice. Our civilization has chosen machinery and medicine and happiness.

352.author: Aldous Huxley
352.quote: An intellectual is a person who's found one thing that's more interesting than sex.

353.author: Aldous Huxley
353.quote: Beauty is worse than wine, it intoxicates both the holder and beholder.

354.author: Aldous Huxley
354.quote: All gods are homemade, and it is we who pull their strings, and so, give them the power to pull ours.

355.author: Aldous Huxley
355.quote: Children are remarkable for their intelligence and ardor, for their curiosity, their intolerance of shams, the clarity and ruthlessness of their vision.

356.author: Aldous Huxley
356.quote: The propagandist's purpose is to make one set of people forget that certain other sets of people are human.

357.author: Aldous Huxley
357.quote: The most valuable of all education is the ability to make yourself do the thing you have to do, when it has to be done, whether you like it or not.

358.author: Aldous Huxley
358.quote: The most shocking fact about war is that its victims and its instruments are individual human beings, and that these individual beings are condemned by the monstrous conventions of politics to murder or be murdered in quarrels not their own.

359.author: Aldous Huxley
359.quote: It is a bit embarrassing to have been concerned with the human problem all one's life and find at the end that one has no more to offer by way of advice than 'try to be a little kinder.'

360.author: Aldous Huxley
360.quote: The charm of history and its enigmatic lesson consist in the fact that, from age to age, nothing changes and yet everything is completely different.

361.author: Aldous Huxley
361.quote: That all men are equal is a proposition to which, at ordinary times, no sane human being has ever given his assent.

362.author: Aldous Huxley
362.quote: The proper study of mankind is books.

363.author: Aldous Huxley
363.quote: So long as men worship the Caesars and Napoleons, Caesars and Napoleons will duly arise and make them miserable.

364.author: Alex Honnold
364.quote: My comfort zone is like a little bubble around me, and I've pushed it in different directions and made it bigger and bigger until these objectives that seemed totally crazy eventually fall within the realm of the possible.

365.author: Alex Honnold
365.quote: No matter the risks we take, we always consider the end to be too soon, even though in life, more than anything else, quality should be more important than quantity.

366.author: Alex Honnold
366.quote: There's a constant tension in climbing, and really all exploration, between pushing yourself into the unknown but trying not to push too far. The best any of us can do is to tread that line carefully.

367.author: Alex Honnold
367.quote: Anytime you finish a climb, there's always the next thing you can try.

368.author: Alex Honnold
368.quote: Yosemite has the most impressive and accessible granite big walls in the world. The rock is amazing. And because of that, it's been the mecca for climbing in the U.S. - and the world to a large degree - for all of climbing history. It's the place to test yourself against the historic routes of the past.

369.author: Alex Honnold
369.quote: To be clear, I normally climb with a rope and partner. Free-soloing makes up only a small percentage of my total climbing. But when I do solo, I manage the risk through careful preparation. I don't solo anything unless I'm sure I can do it.

370.author: Alex Honnold
370.quote: I know that when I'm standing alone below a thousand-foot wall, looking up and considering a climb, my sponsors are the furthest thing from my mind. If I'm going to take risks, they are going to be for myself - not for any company.

371.author: Alex Honnold
371.quote: I'm not thinking about anything when I'm climbing, which is part of the appeal. I'm focused on executing what's in front of me.

372.author: Alex Honnold
372.quote: I often joke that I've just become a professional schmoozer. Like, nobody cares how well I can rock climb anymore. It just has to do with how well I can schmooze.

373.author: Alex Honnold
373.quote: I suppose being a bit of an antisocial weirdo definitely honed my skills as a soloist. It gave me a lot more opportunities to solo lots of easy routes, which in turn broadened my comfort zone quite a bit and has allowed me to climb the harder things without a rope that I've done now.

374.author: Alex Honnold
374.quote: So many people condemn me for risk taking, but I find it sort of hypocritical because everybody takes risks. Even the absence of activity could be viewed as a risk. If you sit on the sofa for your entire life, you're running a higher risk of getting heart disease and cancer.

375.author: Alex Honnold
375.quote: People think I just walk up to a sheer cliff and climb it with no knowledge of anything, when in reality, there's tons and tons of information out there, and I'm already well tapped into it.

376.author: Alex Honnold
376.quote: We are apes - we should be climbing.

377.author: Alex Honnold
377.quote: For sure, Potrero Chico is a super nice winter vacation climbing area. It's really convenient to fly into Monterrey, one of the nicer cities in Mex, and get a taxi to Potero. Then you can just live in the camping area and walk everywhere. It's muy tranquilo, as they say there.

378.author: Alex Honnold
378.quote: Free soloing is almost as old as climbing itself, with roots in the 19th century. Climbers are continuing to push the boundaries. There are certainly better technical climbers than me. But if I have a particular gift, it's a mental one - the ability to keep it together where others might freak out.

379.author: Alex Honnold
379.quote: If you're climbing big routes that'll take you 16 hours, or, like, El Capitan, you have to take something like a big, robust sandwich. Climbing isn't like running or triathlons, where you have to constantly be eating blocks, gels, and pure sugar. Climbing is relatively slow, so you can pretty much eat anything and digest it as you climb.

380.author: Alex Honnold
380.quote: Big climbs energize me. It's all the other aspects of being a pro-climber that wear me down. The travel and expeditions and training can become pretty tiring. But the actual big climbs - that's what I live for.

381.author: Alex Honnold
381.quote: I've done routes where I've climbed 200 feet off the ground and just been, like, 'What am I doing?' I then just climbed back down and went home. Discretion is the better part of valor. Some days are just not your day. That's the big thing with free soloing: when to call it.

382.author: Alex Honnold
382.quote: The diet for climbing all the time isn't really different from the diet for living. It's not like cardio sports where you're burning a bajillion calories every day.

383.author: Alex Honnold
383.quote: I've tried to approach environmentalism the same way I do my climbing: by setting small, concrete goals that build on each other.

384.author: Alex Honnold
384.quote: I think it's great that so many people are enjoying climbing. I've always loved climbing; I don't see why other people wouldn't enjoy it just as much. As long as everyone does their best to respect the areas in which they're climbing, I don't see how the growth of the sport could be a bad thing.

385.author: Alex Honnold
385.quote: I am a vegetarian, and I sort of aspire to vegan-hood. So far I've noticed no difference at all in my climbing, but I feel a bit healthier overall. Though that's only because I'm eating more fruits and vegetables. I think the whole protein thing is overhyped. Most Americans eat far more than we need.

386.author: Alex Honnold
386.quote: I generally don't climb something if it makes me feel fear. The beauty of soloing is that there's no pressure - no one's telling me to do it. So if something seems scary, I don't have any obligation to do it. I can prepare further or just walk away entirely.

387.author: Alex Honnold
387.quote: I'm not nostalgic for my glory days in college. It was lame for me. Probably because I had no friends.

388.author: Alex Honnold
388.quote: Music can be useful during training to help get you psyched, and I still listen to music on easy climbs or in the gym. But during cutting-edge solos or really hard climbs, I unplug. There shouldn't be a need for extra motivation on big days, be it music or anything else. It should come from within.

389.author: Alex Honnold
389.quote: 'Dirtbag' is just the term we use, like a 'gnarly dude' in surfing. Within the climbing culture, it means being a committed lifer: someone who has embraced a minimalist ethic in order to rock climb. It basically means you're a homeless person by choice.

390.author: Alexander Hamilton
390.quote: There is a certain enthusiasm in liberty, that makes human nature rise above itself, in acts of bravery and heroism.

391.author: Alexander Hamilton
391.quote: A well adjusted person is one who makes the same mistake twice without getting nervous.

392.author: Alexander Hamilton
392.quote: I never expect to see a perfect work from an imperfect man.

393.author: Alexander Hamilton
393.quote: A promise must never be broken.

394.author: Alexander Hamilton
394.quote: It's not tyranny we desire; it's a just, limited, federal government.

395.author: Alexander Hamilton
395.quote: I think the first duty of society is justice.

396.author: Alexander Hamilton
396.quote: There are seasons in every country when noise and impudence pass current for worth; and in popular commotions especially, the clamors of interested and factious men are often mistaken for patriotism.

397.author: Alexander Hamilton
397.quote: Even to observe neutrality you must have a strong government.

398.author: Alexander Hamilton
398.quote: Unless your government is respectable, foreigners will invade your rights; and to maintain tranquillity, it must be respectable - even to observe neutrality, you must have a strong government.

399.author: Alexander Hamilton
399.quote: Power over a man's subsistence is power over his will.

400.author: Alexander Hamilton
400.quote: Real firmness is good for anything; strut is good for nothing.

401.author: Alexander Hamilton
401.quote: Real liberty is neither found in despotism or the extremes of democracy, but in moderate governments.

402.author: Alexander Hamilton
402.quote: A national debt, if it is not excessive, will be to us a national blessing.

403.author: Alexander Hamilton
403.quote: The voice of the people has been said to be the voice of God; and, however generally this maxim has been quoted and believed, it is not true to fact. The people are turbulent and changing, they seldom judge or determine right.

404.author: Alexander Hamilton
404.quote: Men often oppose a thing merely because they have had no agency in planning it, or because it may have been planned by those whom they dislike.

405.author: Alexander Hamilton
405.quote: The honor of a nation is its life.

406.author: Alexander Hamilton
406.quote: The sacred rights of mankind are not to be rummaged for among old parchments or musty records. They are written, as with a sunbeam, in the whole volume of human nature, by the hand of the divinity itself; and can never be erased.

407.author: Alexander Hamilton
407.quote: You should not have taken advantage of my sensibility to steal into my affections without my consent.

408.author: Alexander Hamilton
408.quote: When the sword is once drawn, the passions of men observe no bounds of moderation.

409.author: Alexander Hamilton
409.quote: Why has government been instituted at all? Because the passions of men will not conform to the dictates of reason and justice, without constraint.

410.author: Alexander Hamilton
410.quote: The nation which can prefer disgrace to danger is prepared for a master and deserves one.

411.author: Alexander Hamilton
411.quote: In politics, as in religion, it is equally absurd to aim at making proselytes by fire and sword. Heresies in either can rarely be cured by persecution.

412.author: Alexander Hamilton
412.quote: It is the advertiser who provides the paper for the subscriber. It is not to be disputed, that the publisher of a newspaper in this country, without a very exhaustive advertising support, would receive less reward for his labor than the humblest mechanic.

413.author: Alexander Hamilton
413.quote: Let us recollect that peace or war will not always be left to our option; that however moderate or unambitious we may be, we cannot count upon the moderation, or hope to extinguish the ambition of others.

414.author: Alexander Hamilton
414.quote: Safety from external danger is the most powerful director of national conduct. Even the ardent love of liberty will, after a time, give way to its dictates.

415.author: Alexander Hamilton
415.quote: Constitutions should consist only of general provisions; the reason is that they must necessarily be permanent, and that they cannot calculate for the possible change of things.

416.author: Alexander Pope
416.quote: To be angry is to revenge the faults of others on ourselves.

417.author: Alexander Pope
417.quote: To err is human; to forgive, divine.

418.author: Alexander Pope
418.quote: On life's vast ocean diversely we sail. Reasons the card, but passion the gale.

419.author: Alexander Pope
419.quote: Teach me to feel another's woe, to hide the fault I see, that mercy I to others show, that mercy show to me.

420.author: Alexander Pope
420.quote: Charms strike the sight, but merit wins the soul.

421.author: Alexander Pope
421.quote: Fools rush in where angels fear to tread.

422.author: Alexander Pope
422.quote: Blessed is the man who expects nothing, for he shall never be disappointed was the ninth beatitude.

424.author: Alexander Pope
424.quote: So vast is art, so narrow human wit.

425.author: Alexander Pope
425.quote: Praise undeserved, is satire in disguise.

426.author: Alexander Pope
426.quote: No woman ever hates a man for being in love with her, but many a woman hate a man for being a friend to her.

427.author: Alexander Pope
427.quote: Honor and shame from no condition rise. Act well your part: there all the honor lies.

428.author: Alexander Pope
428.quote: Men must be taught as if you taught them not, and things unknown proposed as things forgot.

429.author: Alexander Pope
429.quote: The same ambition can destroy or save, and make a patriot as it makes a knave.

430.author: Alexander Pope
430.quote: For Forms of Government let fools contest; whatever is best administered is best.

431.author: Alexander Pope
431.quote: The greatest magnifying glasses in the world are a man's own eyes when they look upon his own person.

432.author: Alexander Pope
432.quote: Never find fault with the absent.

433.author: Alexander Pope
433.quote: A little learning is a dangerous thing; Drink deep, or taste not the Pierian spring.

434.author: Alexander Pope
434.quote: Beauties in vain their pretty eyes may roll; charms strike the sight, but merit wins the soul.

435.author: Alexander Pope
435.quote: Satan is wiser now than before, and tempts by making rich instead of poor.

436.author: Alexander Pope
436.quote: They dream in courtship, but in wedlock wake.

437.author: Alexander Pope
437.quote: Trust not yourself, but your defects to know, make use of every friend and every foe.

438.author: Alexander Pope
438.quote: The way of the Creative works through change and transformation, so that each thing receives its true nature and destiny and comes into permanent accord with the Great Harmony: this is what furthers and what perseveres.

439.author: Alexander Pope
439.quote: Lo! The poor Indian, whose untutored mind sees God in clouds, or hears him in the wind.

440.author: Alexander Pope
440.quote: I find myself hoping a total end of all the unhappy divisions of mankind by party-spirit, which at best is but the madness of many for the gain of a few.

441.author: Alexander Pope
441.quote: Never elated when someone's oppressed, never dejected when another one's blessed.

442.author: Alexander the Great
442.quote: I am not afraid of an army of lions led by a sheep; I am afraid of an army of sheep led by a lion.

443.author: Alexander the Great
443.quote: There is nothing impossible to him who will try.

444.author: Alexander the Great
444.quote: Whatever possession we gain by our sword cannot be sure or lasting, but the love gained by kindness and moderation is certain and durable.

445.author: Alexander the Great
445.quote: I am indebted to my father for living, but to my teacher for living well.

446.author: Alexander the Great
446.quote: How great are the dangers I face to win a good name in Athens.

447.author: Alexander the Great
447.quote: How should a man be capable of grooming his own horse, or of furbishing his own spear and helmet, if he allows himself to become unaccustomed to tending even his own person, which is his most treasured belonging?

448.author: Alexander the Great
448.quote: You shall, I question not, find a way to the top if you diligently seek for it; for nature hath placed nothing so high that it is out of the reach of industry and valor.

449.author: Alexander the Great
449.quote: Remember upon the conduct of each depends the fate of all.

450.author: Alexander the Great
450.quote: A tomb now suffices him for whom the whole world was not sufficient.

451.author: Alexander the Great
451.quote: Heaven cannot brook two suns, nor earth two masters.

452.author: Alexander the Great
452.quote: I am dying from the treatment of too many physicians.

453.author: Alexander the Great
453.quote: I had rather excel others in the knowledge of what is excellent, than in the extent of my power and dominion.

454.author: Alexander the Great
454.quote: Oh! Most miserable wretch that I am! Why have I not learnt how to swim?

455.author: Alexander the Great
455.quote: I wish that the Indians believed me a god, for upon the report of an enemy's valor oftentimes depends the success of a battle, and false reports have many times done as great things as true courage and resolution.

457.author: Alexander the Great
457.quote: Shall I, that have destroyed my Preservers, return home?

458.author: Alexander the Great
458.quote: If I were not Alexander, I would be Diogenes.

459.author: Alexander the Great
459.quote: How happy had it been for me had I been slain in the battle. It had been far more noble to have died the victim of the enemy than fall a sacrifice to the rage of my friends.

460.author: Alexander the Great
460.quote: So far as I am concerned, I could not be accused of having set eyes, or having wished to set eyes, upon Darius' wife: on the contrary, I have refused even to listen to those who spoke to me of her beauty.

461.author: Alexander the Great
461.quote: For my own part, I would rather excel in knowledge of the highest secrets of philosophy than in arms.

462.author: Alexander the Great
462.quote: Who does not desire such a victory by which we shall join places in our Kingdom, so far divided by nature, and for which we shall set up trophies in another conquered world?

463.author: Alexander the Great
463.quote: If we turn our backs of the Scythians who have provoked us, how shamefully shall we march against the revolted Bactrians; but if we pass Tanais and make the Scythians feel, by dear experience, that we are invincible, not in Asia only, it is not to be doubted but that Europe itself, as well as Asia, will come within the bounds of our conquests.

464.author: Alexander the Great
464.quote: His father is governor of Media, and though he has the greatest command given him of all the rest of my generals, he still covetously desires more, and my being without issue spurs him on to this wicked design. But Philotas takes wrong measures.

465.author: Alexander the Great
465.quote: Soldiers, I had lately like to have been taken from you by the attempt of a few desperate men, but by the grace and providence of the gods, I am still preserved.

466.author: Alexander the Great
466.quote: My father will anticipate everything. He will leave you and me no chance to do a great and brilliant deed.

467.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
467.quote: Healthcare as a human right, it means that every child, no matter where you are born, should have access to a college or trade-school education if they so choose it, and I think no person should be homeless if we can have public structures and public policy to allow for people to have homes and food and lead a dignified life in the United States.

468.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
468.quote: The biggest hurdle that our communities have is cynicism - saying it's a done deal, who cares; there's no point to voting. If we can get somebody to care, it's a huge victory for the movement and the causes we're trying to advance.

469.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
469.quote: Capitalism has not always existed in the world and will not always exist in the world.

470.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
470.quote: I believe that every American should have stable, dignified housing; health care; education - that the most very basic needs to sustain modern life should be guaranteed in a moral society.

471.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
471.quote: When we talk about the word 'socialism,' I think what it really means is just democratic participation in our economic dignity and our economic, social, and racial dignity. It is about direct representation and people actually having power and stake over their economic and social wellness, at the end of the day.

472.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
472.quote: I don't think most of Congress understands how economics works.

473.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
473.quote: To me, what socialism means is to guarantee a basic level of dignity. It's asserting the value of saying that the America we want and the America that we are proud of is one in which all children can access a dignified education. It's one in which no person is too poor to have the medicines they need to live.

475.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
475.quote: For me, democratic socialism is about - really, the value for me is that I believe that in a modern, moral, and wealthy society, no person in America should be too poor to live.

476.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
476.quote: I can't name a single issue with roots in race that doesn't have economic implications, and I cannot think of a single economic issue that doesn't have racial implications. The idea that we have to separate them out and choose one is a con.

477.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
477.quote: I was born in a place where your ZIP code determines your destiny.

478.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
478.quote: I wake up every day, and I'm a Puerto Rican girl from the Bronx. Every single day.

479.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
479.quote: Mentors of mine were under a big pressure to minimize their femininity to make it. I'm not going to do that. That takes away my power. I'm not going to compromise who I am.

480.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
480.quote: The Green New Deal we are proposing will be similar in scale to the mobilization efforts seen in World War II or the Marshall Plan. We must again invest in the development, manufacturing, deployment, and distribution of energy, but this time green energy.

481.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
481.quote: The idea that we're going to austerity ourselves into prosperity is so mistaken, and honestly, I feel like one of the big problems we have is that, because Democrats don't have a deep understanding of or degrees in economics, they allow Wall Street folks to roll in the door and think that they're giving them an education.

482.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
482.quote: Democrats are a big-tent party. You know, I'm not trying to impose an ideology on all, you know, several hundred members of Congress.

483.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
483.quote: What the Bronx and Queens needs is Medicare for all, tuition-free public college, a federal jobs guarantee, and criminal-justice reform.

484.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
484.quote: We are fighting for an unapologetic movement for economic, social, and racial justice in the United States.

485.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
485.quote: I don't think any person in America should die because they are too poor to live.

486.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
486.quote: Democrats should be getting high-fives from sanitation truck drivers - that is what should be happening in America.

487.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
487.quote: I think there's a weapon of cynicism to say, 'Protest doesn't work. Organizing doesn't work. Y'all are a bunch of hippies. You know, it doesn't do anything,' because, frankly, it's said out of fear, because it is a potent force for political change.

488.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
488.quote: If you're differently-abled, if you're a person of color, if you express your identity in a way that's different from the norm, for whatever reason, there's an implicit bias where people, frankly, sometimes take you less seriously.

489.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
489.quote: I do think that sometimes, especially coming into this going straight from activism to being a candidate or to being a person who potentially, you know, looks like will be holding political office soon, I think we expect our politicians to be perfect and fully formed and on point on every single issue.

490.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
490.quote: Our democracy is designed to speak truth to power.

491.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
491.quote: In terms of closing Rikers, we have to close Rikers, but we have to ensure that we're not just taking - that we're not continuing to incarcerate the same level of people. It doesn't do us much good if we close Rikers and then take that same amount of people and just distribute them to be incarcerated elsewhere.

492.author: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
492.quote: I'm not running from the left; I'm running from the bottom. I'm running in fierce advocacy for working-class New Yorkers.

493.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
493.quote: The American Republic will endure until the day Congress discovers that it can bribe the public with the public's money.

494.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
494.quote: History is a gallery of pictures in which there are few originals and many copies.

495.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
495.quote: Democracy and socialism have nothing in common but one word, equality. But notice the difference: while democracy seeks equality in liberty, socialism seeks equality in restraint and servitude.

496.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
496.quote: The greatness of America lies not in being more enlightened than any other nation, but rather in her ability to repair her faults.

497.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
497.quote: When the past no longer illuminates the future, the spirit walks in darkness.

498.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
498.quote: Americans are so enamored of equality that they would rather be equal in slavery than unequal in freedom.

499.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
499.quote: The health of a democratic society may be measured by the quality of functions performed by private citizens.

500.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
500.quote: In the United States, the majority undertakes to supply a multitude of ready-made opinions for the use of individuals, who are thus relieved from the necessity of forming opinions of their own.

501.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
501.quote: Liberty cannot be established without morality, nor morality without faith.

502.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
502.quote: I know of no country in which there is so little independence of mind and real freedom of discussion as in America.

503.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
503.quote: There is hardly a political question in the United States which does not sooner or later turn into a judicial one.

504.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
504.quote: In no other country in the world is the love of property keener or more alert than in the United States, and nowhere else does the majority display less inclination toward doctrines which in any way threaten the way property is owned.

505.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
505.quote: The Americans combine the notions of religion and liberty so intimately in their minds, that it is impossible to make them conceive of one without the other.

506.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
506.quote: The French want no-one to be their superior. The English want inferiors. The Frenchman constantly raises his eyes above him with anxiety. The Englishman lowers his beneath him with satisfaction.

507.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
507.quote: As one digs deeper into the national character of the Americans, one sees that they have sought the value of everything in this world only in the answer to this single question: how much money will it bring in?

508.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
508.quote: The surface of American society is covered with a layer of democratic paint, but from time to time one can see the old aristocratic colours breaking through.

509.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
509.quote: I cannot help fearing that men may reach a point where they look on every new theory as a danger, every innovation as a toilsome trouble, every social advance as a first step toward revolution, and that they may absolutely refuse to move at all.

510.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
510.quote: What is most important for democracy is not that great fortunes should not exist, but that great fortunes should not remain in the same hands. In that way there are rich men, but they do not form a class.

511.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
511.quote: There are many men of principle in both parties in America, but there is no party of principle.

512.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
512.quote: The main business of religions is to purify, control, and restrain that excessive and exclusive taste for well-being which men acquire in times of equality.

513.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
513.quote: All those who seek to destroy the liberties of a democratic nation ought to know that war is the surest and shortest means to accomplish it.

514.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
514.quote: A democratic government is the only one in which those who vote for a tax can escape the obligation to pay it.

515.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
515.quote: Life is to be entered upon with courage.

516.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
516.quote: There is hardly a pioneer's hut which does not contain a few odd volumes of Shakespeare. I remember reading the feudal drama of Henry V for the first time in a log cabin.

517.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
517.quote: The whole life of an American is passed like a game of chance, a revolutionary crisis, or a battle.

518.author: Alexis de Tocqueville
