3570.author: Freddie Mercury
3570.quote: I was never too keen on the British music press. They've called us a supermarket hype, and they used to suggest that we didn't write our own songs.

3572.author: Freddie Mercury
3572.quote: One night Roger was in a foul mood and he threw his entire bloody drumset across the stage. The thing only just missed me - I might have been killed.

3573.author: Freddie Mercury
3573.quote: And, we have no such thing as a budget anymore. Our manager freaks when we show him the bill. We're lavish to the bone, but all our money goes back into the product.

3574.author: Freddie Mercury
3574.quote: You know, I designed the Queen crest. I simply combined all the creatures that represent our star signs-and I don't even believe in astrology.

3575.author: Freddie Mercury
3575.quote: I'm hopeless with money; I simply spend what I've got.

3576.author: Freddie Mercury
3576.quote: We were disliked by the press in the early days because they couldn't put their finger on us, and that was the case with Zeppelin as well.

3577.author: Frederick Douglass
3577.quote: It is easier to build strong children than to repair broken men.

3578.author: Frederick Douglass
3578.quote: If there is no struggle, there is no progress.

3579.author: Frederick Douglass
3579.quote: Where justice is denied, where poverty is enforced, where ignorance prevails, and where any one class is made to feel that society is an organized conspiracy to oppress, rob and degrade them, neither persons nor property will be safe.

3580.author: Frederick Douglass
3580.quote: It is not light that we need, but fire; it is not the gentle shower, but thunder. We need the storm, the whirlwind, and the earthquake.

3581.author: Frederick Douglass
3581.quote: Without a struggle, there can be no progress.

3582.author: Frederick Douglass
3582.quote: The white man's happiness cannot be purchased by the black man's misery.

3583.author: Frederick Douglass
3583.quote: I didn't know I was a slave until I found out I couldn't do the things I wanted.

3584.author: Frederick Douglass
3584.quote: The limits of tyrants are prescribed by the endurance of those whom they oppress.

3585.author: Frederick Douglass
3585.quote: I prayed for twenty years but received no answer until I prayed with my legs.

3586.author: Frederick Douglass
3586.quote: The thing worse than rebellion is the thing that causes rebellion.

3587.author: Frederick Douglass
3587.quote: I prefer to be true to myself, even at the hazard of incurring the ridicule of others, rather than to be false, and to incur my own abhorrence.

3588.author: Frederick Douglass
3588.quote: The life of the nation is secure only while the nation is honest, truthful, and virtuous.

3589.author: Frederick Douglass
3589.quote: A battle lost or won is easily described, understood, and appreciated, but the moral growth of a great nation requires reflection, as well as observation, to appreciate it.

3590.author: Frederick Douglass
3590.quote: To suppress free speech is a double wrong. It violates the rights of the hearer as well as those of the speaker.

3591.author: Frederick Douglass
3591.quote: I am a Republican, a black, dyed in the wool Republican, and I never intend to belong to any other party than the party of freedom and progress.

3592.author: Frederick Douglass
3592.quote: Power concedes nothing without a demand. It never did and it never will.

3593.author: Frederick Douglass
3593.quote: The soul that is within me no man can degrade.

3594.author: Frederick Douglass
3594.quote: Everybody has asked the question, and they learned to ask it early of the abolitionists, 'What shall we do with the Negro?' I have had but one answer from the beginning. Do nothing with us! Your doing with us has already played the mischief with us.

3595.author: Frederick Douglass
3595.quote: I recognize the Republican party as the sheet anchor of the colored man's political hopes and the ark of his safety.

3596.author: Frederick Douglass
3596.quote: We have to do with the past only as we can make it useful to the present and the future.

3597.author: Frederick Douglass
3597.quote: There is not a man beneath the canopy of Heaven who does not know that slavery is wrong for him.

3598.author: Frederick Douglass
3598.quote: Find out just what any people will quietly submit to and you have the exact measure of the injustice and wrong which will be imposed on them.

3599.author: Frederick Douglass
3599.quote: No man can put a chain about the ankle of his fellow man without at last finding the other end fastened about his own neck.

3600.author: Frederick Douglass
3600.quote: A little learning, indeed, may be a dangerous thing, but the want of learning is a calamity to any people.

3601.author: Frederick Douglass
3601.quote: People might not get all they work for in this world, but they must certainly work for all they get.

3602.author: Frederick Douglass
3602.quote: Slaves are generally expected to sing as well as to work.

3603.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3603.quote: It is not a lack of love, but a lack of friendship that makes unhappy marriages.

3604.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3604.quote: To live is to suffer, to survive is to find some meaning in the suffering.

3605.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3605.quote: Thoughts are the shadows of our feelings - always darker, emptier and simpler.

3606.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3606.quote: There is always some madness in love. But there is also always some reason in madness.

3607.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3607.quote: Whenever I climb I am followed by a dog called 'Ego'.

3608.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3608.quote: The individual has always had to struggle to keep from being overwhelmed by the tribe. If you try it, you will be lonely often, and sometimes frightened. But no price is too high to pay for the privilege of owning yourself.

3609.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3609.quote: Love is blind; friendship closes its eyes.

3610.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3610.quote: God is dead. God remains dead. And we have killed him. Yet his shadow still looms. How shall we comfort ourselves, the murderers of all murderers? What was holiest and mightiest of all that the world has yet owned has bled to death under our knives; who will wipe this blood off us? What water is there for us to clean ourselves?

3611.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3611.quote: On the mountains of truth you can never climb in vain: either you will reach a point higher up today, or you will be training your powers so that you will be able to climb higher tomorrow.

3612.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3612.quote: All truly great thoughts are conceived by walking.

3613.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3613.quote: Whoever fights monsters should see to it that in the process he does not become a monster. And if you gaze long enough into an abyss, the abyss will gaze back into you.

3614.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3614.quote: The essence of all beautiful art, all great art, is gratitude.

3615.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3615.quote: In every real man a child is hidden that wants to play.

3616.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3616.quote: Without music, life would be a mistake.

3617.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3617.quote: He who has a why to live can bear almost any how.

3618.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3618.quote: That which does not kill us makes us stronger.

3619.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3619.quote: Hope in reality is the worst of all evils because it prolongs the torments of man.

3620.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3620.quote: One must still have chaos in oneself to be able to give birth to a dancing star.

3621.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3621.quote: When one has not had a good father, one must create one.

3622.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3622.quote: In individuals, insanity is rare; but in groups, parties, nations and epochs, it is the rule.

3623.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3623.quote: There are no facts, only interpretations.

3624.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3624.quote: The most common lie is that which one lies to himself; lying to others is relatively an exception.

3625.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3625.quote: He who would learn to fly one day must first learn to stand and walk and run and climb and dance; one cannot fly into flying.

3627.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
3627.quote: We love life, not because we are used to living but because we are used to loving.

3629.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3629.quote: We sometimes encounter people, even perfect strangers, who begin to interest us at first sight, somehow suddenly, all at once, before a word has been spoken.

3630.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3630.quote: The soul is healed by being with children.

3631.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3631.quote: Much unhappiness has come into the world because of bewilderment and things left unsaid.

3632.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3632.quote: Sarcasm: the last refuge of modest and chaste-souled people when the privacy of their soul is coarsely and intrusively invaded.

3633.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3633.quote: The cleverest of all, in my opinion, is the man who calls himself a fool at least once a month.

3634.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3634.quote: Beauty is mysterious as well as terrible. God and devil are fighting there, and the battlefield is the heart of man.

3635.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3635.quote: A real gentleman, even if he loses everything he owns, must show no emotion. Money must be so far beneath a gentleman that it is hardly worth troubling about.

3636.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3636.quote: The greatest happiness is to know the source of unhappiness.

3637.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3637.quote: Deprived of meaningful work, men and women lose their reason for existence; they go stark, raving mad.

3638.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3638.quote: To love someone means to see him as God intended him.

3639.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3639.quote: Man is fond of counting his troubles, but he does not count his joys. If he counted them up as he ought to, he would see that every lot has enough happiness provided for it.

3640.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3640.quote: If there is no God, everything is permitted.

3641.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3641.quote: It seems, in fact, as though the second half of a man's life is made up of nothing, but the habits he has accumulated during the first half.

3642.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3642.quote: To live without Hope is to Cease to live.

3643.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3643.quote: There are things which a man is afraid to tell even to himself, and every decent man has a number of such things stored away in his mind.

3644.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3644.quote: Happiness does not lie in happiness, but in the achievement of it.

3645.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3645.quote: Men do not accept their prophets and slay them, but they love their martyrs and worship those whom they have tortured to death.

3646.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3646.quote: Realists do not fear the results of their study.

3647.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3647.quote: A novel is a work of poetry. In order to write it, one must have tranquility of spirit and of impression.

3648.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3648.quote: One can know a man from his laugh, and if you like a man's laugh before you know anything of him, you may confidently say that he is a good man.

3649.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3649.quote: Power is given only to those who dare to lower themselves and pick it up. Only one thing matters, one thing; to be able to dare!

3650.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3650.quote: Man, so long as he remains free, has no more constant and agonizing anxiety than find as quickly as possible someone to worship.

3651.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3651.quote: Man only likes to count his troubles, but he does not count his joys.

3652.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3652.quote: If you were to destroy the belief in immortality in mankind, not only love but every living force on which the continuation of all life in the world depended, would dry up at once.

3653.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3653.quote: There is no subject so old that something new cannot be said about it.

3654.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
3654.quote: It is not possible to eat me without insisting that I sing praises of my devourer?

3655.author: Galileo Galilei
3655.quote: We cannot teach people anything; we can only help them discover it within themselves.

3656.author: Galileo Galilei
3656.quote: All truths are easy to understand once they are discovered; the point is to discover them.

3657.author: Galileo Galilei
3657.quote: The Bible shows the way to go to heaven, not the way the heavens go.

3658.author: Galileo Galilei
3658.quote: If I were again beginning my studies, I would follow the advice of Plato and start with mathematics.

3659.author: Galileo Galilei
3659.quote: Measure what is measurable, and make measurable what is not so.

3660.author: Galileo Galilei
3660.quote: Where the senses fail us, reason must step in.

3661.author: Galileo Galilei
3661.quote: I give infinite thanks to God, who has been pleased to make me the first observer of marvelous things.

3662.author: Galileo Galilei
3662.quote: Philosophy is written in this grand book, the universe, which stands continually open to our gaze. But the book cannot be understood unless one first learns to comprehend the language and read the letters in which it is composed.

3663.author: Galileo Galilei
3663.quote: The sun, with all those planets revolving around it and dependent on it, can still ripen a bunch of grapes as if it had nothing else in the universe to do.

3664.author: Galileo Galilei
3664.quote: I have never met a man so ignorant that I couldn't learn something from him.

3665.author: Galileo Galilei
3665.quote: By denying scientific principles, one may maintain any paradox.

3666.author: Galileo Galilei
3666.quote: Nature is relentless and unchangeable, and it is indifferent as to whether its hidden reasons and actions are understandable to man or not.

3668.author: Galileo Galilei
3668.quote: Facts which at first seem improbable will, even on scant explanation, drop the cloak which has hidden them and stand forth in naked and simple beauty.

3669.author: Galileo Galilei
3669.quote: He who looks the higher is the more highly distinguished, and turning over the great book of nature (which is the proper object of philosophy) is the way to elevate one's gaze.

3670.author: Galileo Galilei
3670.quote: I notice that young men go to the universities in order to become doctors or philosophers or anything, so long as it is a title, and that many go in for those professions who are utterly unfit for them, while others who would be very competent are prevented by business or their daily cares, which keep them away from letters.

3671.author: Galileo Galilei
3671.quote: The Milky Way is nothing else but a mass of innumerable stars planted together in clusters.

3672.author: Galileo Galilei
3672.quote: It is surely harmful to souls to make it a heresy to believe what is proved.

3673.author: Galileo Galilei
3673.quote: We must say that there are as many squares as there are numbers.

3674.author: Galileo Galilei
3674.quote: Who would set a limit to the mind of man? Who would dare assert that we know all there is to be known?

3675.author: Galileo Galilei
3675.quote: In questions of science, the authority of a thousand is not worth the humble reasoning of a single individual.

3676.author: Galileo Galilei
3676.quote: I do not feel obliged to believe that the same God who has endowed us with sense, reason, and intellect has intended us to forgo their use.

3677.author: Galileo Galilei
3677.quote: I think that in the discussion of natural problems we ought to begin not with the Scriptures, but with experiments, and demonstrations.

3678.author: Galileo Galilei
3678.quote: It vexes me when they would constrain science by the authority of the Scriptures, and yet do not consider themselves bound to answer reason and experiment.

3679.author: Galileo Galilei
3679.quote: The nature of the human mind is such that unless it is stimulated by images of things acting upon it from without, all remembrance of them passes easily away.

3680.author: George Bernard Shaw
3680.quote: We are made wise not by the recollection of our past, but by the responsibility for our future.

3681.author: George Bernard Shaw
3681.quote: Progress is impossible without change, and those who cannot change their minds cannot change anything.

3682.author: George Bernard Shaw
3682.quote: The single biggest problem in communication is the illusion that it has taken place.

3683.author: George Bernard Shaw
3683.quote: A life spent making mistakes is not only more honorable, but more useful than a life spent doing nothing.

3684.author: George Bernard Shaw
3684.quote: You use a glass mirror to see your face; you use works of art to see your soul.

3685.author: George Bernard Shaw
3685.quote: I learned long ago, never to wrestle with a pig. You get dirty, and besides, the pig likes it.

3686.author: George Bernard Shaw
3686.quote: Alcohol is the anesthesia by which we endure the operation of life.

3687.author: George Bernard Shaw
3687.quote: Beware of false knowledge; it is more dangerous than ignorance.

3688.author: George Bernard Shaw
3688.quote: Success does not consist in never making mistakes but in never making the same one a second time.

3689.author: George Bernard Shaw
3689.quote: Better keep yourself clean and bright; you are the window through which you must see the world.

3690.author: George Bernard Shaw
3690.quote: We don't stop playing because we grow old; we grow old because we stop playing.

3691.author: George Bernard Shaw
3691.quote: You cannot be a hero without being a coward.

3692.author: George Bernard Shaw
3692.quote: Life isn't about finding yourself. Life is about creating yourself.

3693.author: George Bernard Shaw
3693.quote: A gentleman is one who puts more into the world than he takes out.

3694.author: George Bernard Shaw
3694.quote: Silence is the most perfect expression of scorn.

3695.author: George Bernard Shaw
3695.quote: If history repeats itself, and the unexpected always happens, how incapable must Man be of learning from experience.

3696.author: George Bernard Shaw
3696.quote: If you cannot get rid of the family skeleton, you may as well make it dance.

3697.author: George Bernard Shaw
3697.quote: The possibilities are numerous once we decide to act and not react.

3698.author: George Bernard Shaw
3698.quote: Democracy substitutes election by the incompetent many for appointment by the corrupt few.

3699.author: George Bernard Shaw
3699.quote: Marriage is an alliance entered into by a man who can't sleep with the window shut, and a woman who can't sleep with the window open.

3700.author: George Bernard Shaw
3700.quote: The great advantage of a hotel is that it is a refuge from home life.

3701.author: George Bernard Shaw
3701.quote: A happy family is but an earlier heaven.

3702.author: George Bernard Shaw
3702.quote: There is no sincerer love than the love of food.

3703.author: George Bernard Shaw
3703.quote: I have to live for others and not for myself: that's middle-class morality.

3704.author: George Bernard Shaw
3704.quote: You see things; and you say 'Why?' But I dream things that never were; and I say 'Why not?'

3705.author: George Bernard Shaw
3705.quote: Kings are not born: they are made by artificial hallucination.

3706.author: George Burns
3706.quote: Happiness is having a large, loving, caring, close-knit family in another city.

3707.author: George Burns
3707.quote: You can't help getting older, but you don't have to get old.

3708.author: George Burns
3708.quote: If you ask what is the single most important key to longevity, I would have to say it is avoiding worry, stress and tension. And if you didn't ask me, I'd still have to say it.

3709.author: George Burns
3709.quote: It takes only one drink to get me drunk. The trouble is, I can't remember if it's the thirteenth or the fourteenth.

3710.author: George Burns
3710.quote: At my age flowers scare me.

3711.author: George Burns
3711.quote: I spent a year in that town, one Sunday.

3712.author: George Burns
3712.quote: First you forget names, then you forget faces. Next you forget to pull your zipper up and finally, you forget to pull it down.

3713.author: George Burns
3713.quote: Too bad all the people who know how to run this country are busy running taxicabs or cutting hair.

3714.author: George Burns
3714.quote: I honestly think it is better to be a failure at something you love than to be a success at something you hate.

3715.author: George Burns
3715.quote: I'd rather be a failure at something I love than a success at something I hate.

3716.author: George Burns
3716.quote: When I was a boy the Dead Sea was only sick.

3717.author: George Burns
3717.quote: Sex at age 90 is like trying to shoot pool with a rope.

3718.author: George Burns
3718.quote: I smoke ten to fifteen cigars a day. At my age I have to hold on to something.

3719.author: George Burns
3719.quote: The secret of a good sermon is to have a good beginning and a good ending, then having the two as close together as possible.

3720.author: George Burns
3720.quote: Be quick to learn and wise to know.

3721.author: George Burns
3721.quote: Don't stay in bed, unless you can make money in bed.

3722.author: George Burns
3722.quote: You know you're getting old when you stoop to tie your shoelaces and wonder what else you could do while you're down there.

3723.author: George Burns
3723.quote: Too bad that all the people who know how to run the country are busy driving taxicabs and cutting hair.

3724.author: George Burns
3724.quote: I look to the future because that's where I'm going to spend the rest of my life.

3725.author: George Burns
3725.quote: The most important thing in acting is honesty. If you can fake that, you've got it made.

3726.author: George Burns
3726.quote: Happiness? A good cigar, a good meal, a good cigar and a good woman - or a bad woman; it depends on how much happiness you can handle.

3727.author: George Burns
3727.quote: Everything that goes up must come down. But there comes a time when not everything that's down can come up.

3728.author: George Burns
3728.quote: If you live to be one hundred, you've got it made. Very few people die past that age.

3729.author: George Burns
3729.quote: You've got to be honest; if you can fake that, you've got it made.

3730.author: George Burns
3730.quote: Acting is all about honesty. If you can fake that, you've got it made.

3731.author: George Burns
3731.quote: Retirement at sixty-five is ridiculous. When I was sixty-five I still had pimples.

3732.author: George Carlin
3732.quote: May the forces of evil become confused on the way to your house.

3734.author: George Carlin
3734.quote: There are nights when the wolves are silent and only the moon howls.

3735.author: George Carlin
3735.quote: Don't sweat the petty things and don't pet the sweaty things.

3736.author: George Carlin
3736.quote: Just cause you got the monkey off your back doesn't mean the circus has left town.

3737.author: George Carlin
3737.quote: Frisbeetarianism is the belief that when you die, your soul goes up on the roof and gets stuck.

3738.author: George Carlin
3738.quote: Electricity is really just organized lightning.

3739.author: George Carlin
3739.quote: Have you ever noticed that anybody driving slower than you is an idiot, and anyone going faster than you is a maniac?

3740.author: George Carlin
3740.quote: Inside every cynical person, there is a disappointed idealist.

3741.author: George Carlin
3741.quote: I went to a bookstore and asked the saleswoman, 'Where's the self-help section?' She said if she told me, it would defeat the purpose.

3742.author: George Carlin
3742.quote: Some people see things that are and ask, Why? Some people dream of things that never were and ask, Why not? Some people have to go to work and don't have time for all that.

3743.author: George Carlin
3743.quote: Most people work just hard enough not to get fired and get paid just enough money not to quit.

3744.author: George Carlin
3744.quote: Well, if crime fighters fight crime and fire fighters fight fire, what do freedom fighters fight? They never mention that part to us, do they?

3745.author: George Carlin
3745.quote: If you can't beat them, arrange to have them beaten.

3746.author: George Carlin
3746.quote: One tequila, two tequila, three tequila, floor.

3747.author: George Carlin
3747.quote: 'I am' is reportedly the shortest sentence in the English language. Could it be that 'I do' is the longest sentence?

3748.author: George Carlin
3748.quote: One can never know for sure what a deserted area looks like.

3749.author: George Carlin
3749.quote: When Thomas Edison worked late into the night on the electric light, he had to do it by gas lamp or candle. I'm sure it made the work seem that much more urgent.

3751.author: George Carlin
3751.quote: When you're born you get a ticket to the freak show. When you're born in America, you get a front row seat.

3752.author: George Carlin
3752.quote: There's no present. There's only the immediate future and the recent past.

3754.author: George Carlin
3754.quote: Not only do I not know what's going on, I wouldn't know what to do about it if I did.

3755.author: George Carlin
3755.quote: In comic strips, the person on the left always speaks first.

3756.author: George Carlin
3756.quote: I'm always relieved when someone is delivering a eulogy and I realize I'm listening to it.

3757.author: George Carlin
3757.quote: The very existence of flame-throwers proves that some time, somewhere, someone said to themselves, You know, I want to set those people over there on fire, but I'm just not close enough to get the job done.

3758.author: George Eliot
3758.quote: Life began with waking up and loving my mother's face.

3759.author: George Eliot
3759.quote: Delicious autumn! My very soul is wedded to it, and if I were a bird I would fly about the earth seeking the successive autumns.

3760.author: George Eliot
3760.quote: It is never too late to be what you might have been.

3761.author: George Eliot
3761.quote: The beginning of compunction is the beginning of a new life.

3762.author: George Eliot
3762.quote: Animals are such agreeable friends - they ask no questions; they pass no criticisms.

3763.author: George Eliot
3763.quote: It will never rain roses: when we want to have more roses we must plant more trees.

3764.author: George Eliot
3764.quote: Great things are not done by impulse, but by a series of small things brought together.

3765.author: George Eliot
3765.quote: Wear a smile and have friends; wear a scowl and have wrinkles.

3766.author: George Eliot
3766.quote: The reward of one duty is the power to fulfill another.

3767.author: George Eliot
3767.quote: The strongest principle of growth lies in the human choice.

3768.author: George Eliot
3768.quote: Blessed is the influence of one true, loving human soul on another.

3769.author: George Eliot
3769.quote: No story is the same to us after a lapse of time; or rather we who read it are no longer the same interpreters.

3770.author: George Eliot
3770.quote: What do we live for, if not to make life less difficult for each other?

3771.author: George Eliot
3771.quote: Our dead are never dead to us, until we have forgotten them.

3772.author: George Eliot
3772.quote: It is easy to say how we love new friends, and what we think of them, but words can never trace out all the fibers that knit us to the old.

3773.author: George Eliot
3773.quote: The golden moments in the stream of life rush past us, and we see nothing but sand; the angels come to visit us, and we only know them when they are gone.

3774.author: George Eliot
3774.quote: An election is coming. Universal peace is declared, and the foxes have a sincere interest in prolonging the lives of the poultry.

3775.author: George Eliot
3775.quote: You may try but you can never imagine what it is to have a man's form of genius in you, and to suffer the slavery of being a girl.

3776.author: George Eliot
3776.quote: If we had a keen vision of all that is ordinary in human life, it would be like hearing the grass grow or the squirrel's heart beat, and we should die of that roar which is the other side of silence.

3777.author: George Eliot
3777.quote: What greater thing is there for two human souls than to feel that they are joined - to strengthen each other - to be at one with each other in silent unspeakable memories.

3778.author: George Eliot
3778.quote: You should read history and look at ostracism, persecution, martyrdom, and that kind of thing. They always happen to the best men, you know.

3779.author: George Eliot
3779.quote: The egoism which enters into our theories does not affect their sincerity; rather, the more our egoism is satisfied, the more robust is our belief.

3780.author: George Eliot
3780.quote: Failure after long perseverance is much grander than never to have a striving good enough to be called a failure.

3781.author: George Eliot
3781.quote: Rome - the city of visible history, where the past of a whole hemisphere seems moving in funeral procession with strange ancestral images and trophies gathered from afar.

3782.author: George Eliot
3782.quote: Only in the agony of parting do we look into the depths of love.

3783.author: George Eliot
3783.quote: It seems to me we can never give up longing and wishing while we are thoroughly alive. There are certain things we feel to be beautiful and good, and we must hunger after them.

3784.author: George Orwell
3784.quote: War is peace. Freedom is slavery. Ignorance is strength.

3785.author: George Orwell
3785.quote: Happiness can exist only in acceptance.

3786.author: George Orwell
3786.quote: In our age there is no such thing as 'keeping out of politics.' All issues are political issues, and politics itself is a mass of lies, evasions, folly, hatred and schizophrenia.

3787.author: George Orwell
3787.quote: Nationalism is power hunger tempered by self-deception.

3788.author: George Orwell
3788.quote: Power is not a means, it is an end. One does not establish a dictatorship in order to safeguard a revolution; one makes the revolution in order to establish the dictatorship.

3789.author: George Orwell
3789.quote: The very concept of objective truth is fading out of the world. Lies will pass into history.

3791.author: George Orwell
3791.quote: We sleep safe in our beds because rough men stand ready in the night to visit violence on those who would do us harm.

3792.author: George Orwell
3792.quote: The essence of being human is that one does not seek perfection.

3793.author: George Orwell
3793.quote: All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others.

3794.author: George Orwell
3794.quote: Political language... is designed to make lies sound truthful and murder respectable, and to give an appearance of solidity to pure wind.

3795.author: George Orwell
3795.quote: If you want a vision of the future, imagine a boot stamping on a human face - forever.

3796.author: George Orwell
3796.quote: If liberty means anything at all, it means the right to tell people what they do not want to hear.

3797.author: George Orwell
3797.quote: But if thought corrupts language, language can also corrupt thought.

3798.author: George Orwell
3798.quote: Serious sport has nothing to do with fair play. It is bound up with hatred, jealousy, boastfulness, disregard of all rules and sadistic pleasure in witnessing violence. In other words, it is war minus the shooting.

3799.author: George Orwell
3799.quote: The nationalist not only does not disapprove of atrocities committed by his own side, but he has a remarkable capacity for not even hearing about them.

3800.author: George Orwell
3800.quote: Sometimes the first duty of intelligent men is the restatement of the obvious.

3801.author: George Orwell
3801.quote: There are some ideas so wrong that only a very intelligent person could believe in them.

3802.author: George Orwell
3802.quote: It is almost universally felt that when we call a country democratic we are praising it; consequently, the defenders of every kind of regime claim that it is a democracy, and fear that they might have to stop using the word if it were tied down to any one meaning.

3803.author: George Orwell
3803.quote: Mankind is not likely to salvage civilization unless he can evolve a system of good and evil which is independent of heaven and hell.

3804.author: George Orwell
3804.quote: Each generation imagines itself to be more intelligent than the one that went before it, and wiser than the one that comes after it.

3805.author: George Orwell
3805.quote: We have now sunk to a depth at which restatement of the obvious is the first duty of intelligent men.

3806.author: George Orwell
3806.quote: The quickest way of ending a war is to lose it.

3807.author: George Orwell
3807.quote: One cannot really be a Catholic and grown up.

3808.author: George Orwell
3808.quote: Freedom is the right to tell people what they do not want to hear.

3809.author: George Orwell
3809.quote: Who controls the past controls the future. Who controls the present controls the past.

3810.author: George S. Patton
3810.quote: Accept the challenges so that you can feel the exhilaration of victory.

3811.author: George S. Patton
3811.quote: It is foolish and wrong to mourn the men who died. Rather we should thank God that such men lived.

3812.author: George S. Patton
3812.quote: A good plan violently executed now is better than a perfect plan executed next week.

3813.author: George S. Patton
3813.quote: You need to overcome the tug of people against you as you reach for high goals.

3814.author: George S. Patton
3814.quote: If everyone is thinking alike, then somebody isn't thinking.

3815.author: George S. Patton
3815.quote: Success is how high you bounce when you hit bottom.

3816.author: George S. Patton
3816.quote: The object of war is not to die for your country but to make the other bastard die for his.

3817.author: George S. Patton
3817.quote: Battle is the most magnificent competition in which a human being can indulge. It brings out all that is best; it removes all that is base. All men are afraid in battle. The coward is the one who lets his fear overcome his sense of duty. Duty is the essence of manhood.

3818.author: George S. Patton
3818.quote: Better to fight for something than live for nothing.

3819.author: George S. Patton
3819.quote: Wars may be fought with weapons, but they are won by men. It is the spirit of men who follow and of the man who leads that gains the victory.

3820.author: George S. Patton
3820.quote: Courage is fear holding on a minute longer.

3821.author: George S. Patton
3821.quote: Never tell people how to do things. Tell them what to do and they will surprise you with their ingenuity.

3822.author: George S. Patton
3822.quote: We herd sheep, we drive cattle, we lead people. Lead me, follow me, or get out of my way.

3823.author: George S. Patton
3823.quote: If you tell people where to go, but not how to get there, you'll be amazed at the results.

3824.author: George S. Patton
3824.quote: Prepare for the unknown by studying how others in the past have coped with the unforeseeable and the unpredictable.

3825.author: George S. Patton
3825.quote: Don't tell people how to do things, tell them what to do and let them surprise you with their results.

3826.author: George S. Patton
3826.quote: If we take the generally accepted definition of bravery as a quality which knows no fear, I have never seen a brave man. All men are frightened. The more intelligent they are, the more they are frightened.

3827.author: George S. Patton
3827.quote: Nobody ever defended anything successfully, there is only attack and attack and attack some more.

3828.author: George S. Patton
3828.quote: There is only one sort of discipline, perfect discipline.

3829.author: George S. Patton
3829.quote: Watch what people are cynical about, and one can often discover what they lack.

3830.author: George S. Patton
3830.quote: The time to take counsel of your fears is before you make an important battle decision. That's the time to listen to every fear you can imagine! When you have collected all the facts and fears and made your decision, turn off all your fears and go ahead!

3831.author: George S. Patton
3831.quote: Take calculated risks. That is quite different from being rash.

3832.author: George S. Patton
3832.quote: Always do everything you ask of those you command.

3833.author: George S. Patton
3833.quote: If a man does his best, what else is there?

3834.author: George S. Patton
3834.quote: All very successful commanders are prima donnas and must be so treated.

3835.author: George S. Patton
3835.quote: There is a time to take counsel of your fears, and there is a time to never listen to any fear.

3836.author: George Sand
3836.quote: There is only one happiness in this life, to love and be loved.

3837.author: George Sand
3837.quote: Try to keep your soul young and quivering right up to old age.

3838.author: George Sand
3838.quote: Life in common among people who love each other is the ideal of happiness.

3839.author: George Sand
3839.quote: The prayers of a lover are more imperious than the menaces of the whole world.

3840.author: George Sand
3840.quote: The artist vocation is to send light into the human heart.

3841.author: George Sand
3841.quote: Guard well within yourself that treasure, kindness. Know how to give without hesitation, how to lose without regret, how to acquire without meanness.

3842.author: George Sand
3842.quote: Simplicity is the most difficult thing to secure in this world; it is the last limit of experience and the last effort of genius.

3843.author: George Sand
3843.quote: Once my heart was captured, reason was shown the door, deliberately and with a sort of frantic joy. I accepted everything, I believed everything, without struggle, without suffering, without regret, without false shame. How can one blush for what one adores?

3845.author: George Sand
3845.quote: Don't walk in front of me, I may not follow. Don't walk behind me, I may not lead. There is only one happiness in life, to love and be loved.

3846.author: George Sand
3846.quote: No human creature can give orders to love.

3847.author: George Sand
3847.quote: We cannot tear out a single page of our life, but we can throw the whole book in the fire.

3848.author: George Sand
3848.quote: Every historian discloses a new horizon.

3849.author: George Sand
3849.quote: Vanity is the quicksand of reason.

3850.author: George Sand
3850.quote: Charity degrades those who receive it and hardens those who dispense it.

3851.author: George Sand
3851.quote: Faith is an excitement and an enthusiasm: it is a condition of intellectual magnificence to which we must cling as to a treasure, and not squander on our way through life in the small coin of empty words, or in exact and priggish argument.

3852.author: George Sand
3852.quote: Life resembles a novel more often than novels resemble life.

3853.author: George Sand
3853.quote: I have no enthusiasm for nature which the slightest chill will not instantly destroy.

3854.author: George Sand
3854.quote: The beauty that addresses itself to the eyes is only the spell of the moment; the eye of the body is not always that of the soul.

3855.author: George Sand
3855.quote: He who draws noble delights from sentiments of poetry is a true poet, though he has never written a line in all his life.

3856.author: George Sand
3856.quote: Work is not man's punishment. It is his reward and his strength and his pleasure.

3857.author: George Sand
3857.quote: Women love always: when earth slips from them, they take refuge in heaven.

3858.author: George Sand
3858.quote: One changes from day to day, and... after a few years have passed one has completely altered.

3859.author: George Sand
3859.quote: The trade of authorship is a violent, and indestructible obsession.

3860.author: George Sand
3860.quote: No one makes a revolution by himself; and there are some revolutions which humanity accomplishes without quite knowing how, because it is everybody who takes them in hand.

3861.author: George Sand
3861.quote: I see upon their noble brows the seal of the Lord, for they were born kings of the earth far more truly than those who possess it only from having bought it.

3862.author: George Santayana
3862.quote: The family is one of nature's masterpieces.

3863.author: George Santayana
3863.quote: Those who do not remember the past are condemned to repeat it.

3864.author: George Santayana
3864.quote: A child educated only at school is an uneducated child.

3865.author: George Santayana
3865.quote: We must welcome the future, remembering that soon it will be the past; and we must respect the past, remembering that it was once all that was humanly possible.

3866.author: George Santayana
3866.quote: A man's feet should be planted in his country, but his eyes should survey the world.

3867.author: George Santayana
3867.quote: To be interested in the changing seasons is a happier state of mind than to be hopelessly in love with spring.

3868.author: George Santayana
3868.quote: An artist is a dreamer consenting to dream of the actual world.

3869.author: George Santayana
3869.quote: The young man who has not wept is a savage, and the older man who will not laugh is a fool.

3870.author: George Santayana
3870.quote: The world is a perpetual caricature of itself; at every moment it is the mockery and the contradiction of what it is pretending to be.

3871.author: George Santayana
3871.quote: Only the dead have seen the end of the war.

3872.author: George Santayana
3872.quote: A string of excited, fugitive, miscellaneous pleasures is not happiness; happiness resides in imaginative reflection and judgment, when the picture of one's life, or of human life, as it truly has been or is, satisfies the will, and is gladly accepted.

3873.author: George Santayana
3873.quote: Fashion is something barbarous, for it produces innovation without reason and imitation without benefit.

3874.author: George Santayana
3874.quote: Religion in its humility restores man to his only dignity, the courage to live by grace.

3875.author: George Santayana
3875.quote: When men and women agree, it is only in their conclusions; their reasons are always different.

3876.author: George Santayana
3876.quote: Graphic design is the paradise of individuality, eccentricity, heresy, abnormality, hobbies and humors.

3877.author: George Santayana
3877.quote: It is a revenge the devil sometimes takes upon the virtuous, that he entraps them by the force of the very passion they have suppressed and think themselves superior to.

3878.author: George Santayana
3878.quote: The passions grafted on wounded pride are the most inveterate; they are green and vigorous in old age.

3879.author: George Santayana
3879.quote: The Difficult is that which can be done immediately; the Impossible that which takes a little longer.

3880.author: George Santayana
3880.quote: Oxford, the paradise of dead philosophies.

3881.author: George Santayana
3881.quote: In Greece wise men speak and fools decide.

3882.author: George Santayana
3882.quote: Never build your emotional life on the weaknesses of others.

3883.author: George Santayana
3883.quote: Nonsense is so good only because common sense is so limited.

3884.author: George Santayana
3884.quote: Fanaticism consists of redoubling your effort when you have forgotten your aim.

3885.author: George Santayana
3885.quote: To know what people really think, pay regard to what they do, rather than what they say.

3887.author: George Santayana
3887.quote: To me, it seems a dreadful indignity to have a soul controlled by geography.

3888.author: George Washington
3888.quote: It is far better to be alone, than to be in bad company.

3889.author: George Washington
3889.quote: Observe good faith and justice toward all nations. Cultivate peace and harmony with all.

3890.author: George Washington
3890.quote: If the freedom of speech is taken away then dumb and silent we may be led, like sheep to the slaughter.

3891.author: George Washington
3891.quote: To be prepared for war is one of the most effective means of preserving peace.

3892.author: George Washington
3892.quote: Truth will ultimately prevail where there is pains to bring it to light.

3893.author: George Washington
3893.quote: The Constitution is the guide which I never will abandon.

3894.author: George Washington
3894.quote: Liberty, when it begins to take root, is a plant of rapid growth.

3895.author: George Washington
3895.quote: True friendship is a plant of slow growth, and must undergo and withstand the shocks of adversity, before it is entitled to the appellation.

3896.author: George Washington
3896.quote: Happiness and moral duty are inseparably connected.

3897.author: George Washington
3897.quote: Guard against the impostures of pretended patriotism.

3898.author: George Washington
3898.quote: My first wish is to see this plague of mankind, war, banished from the earth.

3899.author: George Washington
3899.quote: It is better to offer no excuse than a bad one.

3900.author: George Washington
3900.quote: Discipline is the soul of an army. It makes small numbers formidable; procures success to the weak, and esteem to all.

3901.author: George Washington
3901.quote: Associate with men of good quality if you esteem your own reputation; for it is better to be alone than in bad company.

3902.author: George Washington
3902.quote: Mankind, when left to themselves, are unfit for their own government.

3903.author: George Washington
3903.quote: The basis of our political system is the right of the people to make and to alter their constitutions of government.

3904.author: George Washington
3904.quote: Labor to keep alive in your breast that little spark of celestial fire, called conscience.

3905.author: George Washington
3905.quote: I can only say that there is not a man living who wishes more sincerely than I do, to see a plan adopted for the abolition of it - but there is only one proper and effectual mode by which it can be accomplished, and that is by Legislative authority: and this, as far as my suffrage will go, shall never be wanting.

3906.author: George Washington
3906.quote: It is better to be alone than in bad company.

3907.author: George Washington
3907.quote: I hope I shall possess firmness and virtue enough to maintain what I consider the most enviable of all titles, the character of an honest man.

3908.author: George Washington
3908.quote: Few men have virtue to withstand the highest bidder.

3909.author: George Washington
3909.quote: There is nothing which can better deserve your patronage, than the promotion of science and literature. Knowledge is in every country the surest basis of public happiness.

3910.author: George Washington
3910.quote: Worry is the interest paid by those who borrow trouble.

3911.author: George Washington
3911.quote: When we assumed the Soldier, we did not lay aside the Citizen.

3912.author: George Washington
3912.quote: The alternate domination of one faction over another, sharpened by the spirit of revenge natural to party dissension, which in different ages and countries has perpetrated the most horrid enormities, is itself a frightful despotism. But this leads at length to a more formal and permanent despotism.

3913.author: George Washington
3913.quote: We should not look back unless it is to derive useful lessons from past errors, and for the purpose of profiting by dearly bought experience.

3914.author: George Washington Carver
3914.quote: Education is the key to unlock the golden door of freedom.

3915.author: George Washington Carver
3915.quote: Where there is no vision, there is no hope.

3916.author: George Washington Carver
3916.quote: Nothing is more beautiful than the loveliness of the woods before sunrise.

3917.author: George Washington Carver
3917.quote: Ninety-nine percent of the failures come from people who have the habit of making excuses.

3918.author: George Washington Carver
3918.quote: I wanted to know the name of every stone and flower and insect and bird and beast. I wanted to know where it got its color, where it got its life - but there was no one to tell me.

3919.author: George Washington Carver
3919.quote: How far you go in life depends on your being tender with the young, compassionate with the aged, sympathetic with the striving and tolerant of the weak and strong. Because someday in your life you will have been all of these.

3920.author: George Washington Carver
3920.quote: There is no short cut to achievement. Life requires thorough preparation - veneer isn't worth anything.

3921.author: George Washington Carver
3921.quote: From a child, I had an inordinate desire for knowledge and especially music, painting, flowers, and the sciences, Algebra being one of my favorite studies.

3922.author: George Washington Carver
3922.quote: When you can do the common things of life in an uncommon way, you will command the attention of the world.

3923.author: George Washington Carver
3923.quote: It is not the style of clothes one wears, neither the kind of automobile one drives, nor the amount of money one has in the bank, that counts. These mean nothing. It is simply service that measures success.

3924.author: George Washington Carver
3924.quote: Since new developments are the products of a creative mind, we must therefore stimulate and encourage that type of mind in every way possible.

3925.author: George Washington Carver
3925.quote: I love to think of nature as an unlimited broadcasting station, through which God speaks to us every hour, if we will only tune in.

3926.author: George Washington Carver
3926.quote: No books ever go into my laboratory. The thing I am to do and the way are revealed to me the moment I am inspired to create something new. Without God to draw aside the curtain, I would be helpless. Only alone can I draw close enough to God to discover His secrets.

3927.author: George Washington Carver
3927.quote: No individual has any right to come into the world and go out of it without leaving behind him distinct and legitimate reasons for having passed through it.

3928.author: George Washington Carver
3928.quote: Reading about nature is fine, but if a person walks in the woods and listens carefully, he can learn more than what is in books, for they speak with the voice of God.

3929.author: George Washington Carver
3929.quote: Anything will give up its secrets if you love it enough. Not only have I found that when I talk to the little flower or to the little peanut they will give up their secrets, but I have found that when I silently commune with people, they give up their secrets also - if you love them enough.

3930.author: George Washington Carver
3930.quote: Years ago I went into my laboratory and said, 'Dear Mr. Creator, please tell me what the universe was made for?' The Great Creator answered, 'You want to know too much for that little mind of yours. Ask for something more your size, little man.'

3931.author: George Washington Carver
3931.quote: Fear of something is at the root of hate for others, and hate within will eventually destroy the hater.

3932.author: George Washington Carver
3932.quote: God cannot use you as He wishes until you come into the fullness of His Glory. Do not get alarmed, my friend, when doubts creep in. That is old Satan. Pray, pray, pray.

3933.author: George Washington Carver
3933.quote: I would never allow anyone to give me money, no difference how badly I needed it. I wanted literally to earn my living.

3934.author: George Washington Carver
3934.quote: Human need is really a great spiritual vacuum which God seeks to fill... With one hand in the hand of a fellow man in need and the other in the hand of Christ, He could get across the vacuum.

3935.author: George Washington Carver
3935.quote: Our creator is the same and never changes despite the names given Him by people here and in all parts of the world. Even if we gave Him no name at all, He would still be there, within us, waiting to give us good on this earth.

3936.author: George Washington Carver
3936.quote: When our thoughts - which bring actions - are filled with hate against anyone, Negro or white, we are in a living hell. That is as real as hell will ever be.

3937.author: George Washington Carver
3937.quote: If you love it enough, anything will talk with you.

3938.author: George Washington Carver
3938.quote: We have become 99 percent money mad. The method of living at home modestly and within our income, laying a little by systematically for the proverbial rainy day which is due to come, can almost be listed among the lost arts.

3939.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3939.quote: There are no rules of architecture for a castle in the clouds.

3940.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3940.quote: When it comes to life the critical thing is whether you take things for granted or take them with gratitude.

3941.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3941.quote: And when it rains on your parade, look up rather than down. Without the rain, there would be no rainbow.

3942.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3942.quote: I would maintain that thanks are the highest form of thought, and that gratitude is happiness doubled by wonder.

3943.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3943.quote: One sees great things from the valley; only small things from the peak.

3944.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3944.quote: The traveler sees what he sees, the tourist sees what he has come to see.

3946.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3946.quote: The true object of all human life is play. Earth is a task garden; heaven is a playground.

3947.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3947.quote: Art consists of limitation. The most beautiful part of every picture is the frame.

3948.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3948.quote: The way to love anything is to realize that it may be lost.

3949.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3949.quote: Brave men are all vertebrates; they have their softness on the surface and their toughness in the middle.

3950.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3950.quote: If I can put one touch of rosy sunset into the life of any man or woman, I shall feel that I have worked with God.

3951.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3951.quote: The aim of life is appreciation; there is no sense in not appreciating things; and there is no sense in having more of them if you have less appreciation of them.

3952.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3952.quote: Tolerance is the virtue of the man without convictions.

3953.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3953.quote: All architecture is great architecture after sunset; perhaps architecture is really a nocturnal art, like the art of fireworks.

3954.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3954.quote: Lying in bed would be an altogether perfect and supreme experience if only one had a colored pencil long enough to draw on the ceiling.

3955.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3955.quote: Thieves respect property. They merely wish the property to become their property that they may more perfectly respect it.

3956.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3956.quote: Marriage is an adventure, like going to war.

3957.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3957.quote: Do not free a camel of the burden of his hump; you may be freeing him from being a camel.

3958.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3958.quote: Democracy means government by the uneducated, while aristocracy means government by the badly educated.

3959.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3959.quote: Youth is the period in which a man can be hopeless. The end of every episode is the end of the world. But the power of hoping through everything, the knowledge that the soul survives its adventures, that great inspiration comes to the middle-aged.

3960.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3960.quote: The poets have been mysteriously silent on the subject of cheese.

3961.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3961.quote: The object of a New Year is not that we should have a new year. It is that we should have a new soul and a new nose; new feet, a new backbone, new ears, and new eyes. Unless a particular man made New Year resolutions, he would make no resolutions. Unless a man starts afresh about things, he will certainly do nothing effective.

3962.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3962.quote: Love means to love that which is unlovable; or it is no virtue at all.

3963.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3963.quote: Christianity has not been tried and found wanting; it has been found difficult and not tried.

3964.author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
3964.quote: True contentment is a thing as active as agriculture. It is the power of getting out of any situation all that there is in it. It is arduous and it is rare.

3965.author: Gordon Ramsay
3965.quote: I don't like looking back. I'm always constantly looking forward. I'm not the one to sort of sit and cry over spilt milk. I'm too busy looking for the next cow.

3966.author: Gordon Ramsay
3966.quote: If you want to become a great chef, you have to work with great chefs. And that's exactly what I did.

3967.author: Gordon Ramsay
3967.quote: Cooking is about passion, so it may look slightly temperamental in a way that it's too assertive to the naked eye.

3968.author: Gordon Ramsay
3968.quote: I cook, I create, I'm incredibly excited by what I do, I've still got a lot to achieve.

3969.author: Gordon Ramsay
3969.quote: I am what I am. A fighter.

3970.author: Gordon Ramsay
3970.quote: When you cook under pressure you trade perfection.

3971.author: Gordon Ramsay
3971.quote: There's a bond among a kitchen staff, I think. You spend more time with your chef in the kitchen than you do with your own family.

3972.author: Gordon Ramsay
3972.quote: The pressure on young chefs today is far greater than ever before in terms of social skills, marketing skills, cooking skills, personality and, more importantly, delivering on the plate. So you need to be strong. Physically fit. So my chefs get weighed every time they come into the kitchen.

3973.author: Gordon Ramsay
3973.quote: If I can give you one strong piece of advice, when you go away for that romantic weekend, whatever you do, do not accept or take the upgrade to the honeymoon suite.

3974.author: Gordon Ramsay
3974.quote: If I relaxed, if I took my foot off the gas, I would probably die.

3975.author: Gordon Ramsay
3975.quote: I've had a lot of success; I've had failures, so I learn from the failure.

3976.author: Gordon Ramsay
3976.quote: Swearing is industry language. For as long as we're alive it's not going to change. You've got to be boisterous to get results.

3977.author: Gordon Ramsay
3977.quote: The minute you start compromising for the sake of massaging somebody's ego, that's it, game over.

3978.author: Gordon Ramsay
3978.quote: Cooking today is a young man's game, I don't give a bollocks what anyone says.

3980.author: Gordon Ramsay
3980.quote: Chefs are nutters. They're all self-obsessed, delicate, dainty, insecure little souls and absolute psychopaths. Every last one of them.

3981.author: Gordon Ramsay
3981.quote: Kitchens are hard environments and they form incredibly strong characters.

3982.author: Gordon Ramsay
3982.quote: I suppose your security is your success and your key to success is your fine palate.

3983.author: Gordon Ramsay
3983.quote: I'm Gordon Ramsay, for goodness sake: people know I'm volatile.

3984.author: Gordon Ramsay
3984.quote: We are about creating a new wave of talent. We are the Manchester United of kitchens now. Am I playing full-time in the kitchen? I am a player-coach.

3985.author: Gordon Ramsay
3985.quote: Find what's hot, find what's just opened and then look for the worst review of the week. There is so much to learn from watching a restaurant getting absolutely panned and having a bad experience. Go and see it for yourself.

3986.author: Gordon Ramsay
3986.quote: I think every chef, not just in America, but across the world, has a double-edged sword - two jackets, one that's driven, a self-confessed perfectionist, thoroughbred, hate incompetence and switch off the stove, take off the jacket and become a family man.

3987.author: Gordon Ramsay
3987.quote: I still love football, though, and I think cooking is like football. It's not a job, it's a passion. When you become good at it, it's a dream job and financially you need never to worry. Ever.

3988.author: Gordon Ramsay
3988.quote: I didn't get depressed, I don't get depressed.

3990.author: Gordon Ramsay
3990.quote: As a soccer player, I wanted an FA Cup winner's medal. As an actor you want an Oscar. As a chef it's three-Michelin's stars, there's no greater than that. So pushing yourself to the extreme creates a lot of pressure and a lot of excitement, and more importantly, it shows on the plate.

3991.author: Gore Vidal
3991.quote: Style is knowing who you are, what you want to say, and not giving a damn.

3992.author: Gore Vidal
3992.quote: At any given moment, public opinion is a chaos of superstition, misinformation and prejudice.

3993.author: Gore Vidal
3993.quote: As societies grow decadent, the language grows decadent, too. Words are used to disguise, not to illuminate, action: you liberate a city by destroying it. Words are to confuse, so that at election time people will solemnly vote against their own interests.

3994.author: Gore Vidal
3994.quote: By 1939, the Depression was back. Unemployment was huge. Roosevelt didn't have any quick fix. Remember, the New Deal, Works Progress Administration, and Civilian Conservation Corps - all that happened years before. Roosevelt was riding a storm.

3995.author: Gore Vidal
3995.quote: Because there is no cosmic point to the life that each of us perceives on this distant bit of dust at the galaxy's edge... there is all the more reason for us to maintain in proper balance what we have here. Because there is nothing else. No thing. This is it. And quite enough, all in all.

3996.author: Gore Vidal
3996.quote: We are the United States of Amnesia, which is encouraged by a media that has no desire to tell us the truth about anything, serving their corporate masters who have other plans to dominate us.

3997.author: Gore Vidal
3997.quote: There is no such thing as a homosexual or a heterosexual person. There are only homo- or heterosexual acts. Most people are a mixture of impulses if not practices.

3998.author: Gore Vidal
3998.quote: Every country should have at least one King Farouk.

3999.author: Gore Vidal
3999.quote: Think of the earth as a living organism that is being attacked by billions of bacteria whose numbers double every forty years. Either the host dies, or the virus dies, or both die.

4000.author: Gore Vidal
4000.quote: The corporate grip on opinion in the United States is one of the wonders of the Western world. No First World country has ever managed to eliminate so entirely from its media all objectivity - much less dissent.

4001.author: Gore Vidal
4001.quote: You cannot deprive somebody of life, liberty, pursuit of happiness, because that is a right - constitutional right.

4002.author: Gore Vidal
4002.quote: In August 1961, I visited President Kennedy at Hyannis Port. The Berlin Wall was going up, and he was about to begin a huge military buildup - reluctantly, or so he said, as he puffed on a cigar liberated by a friend from Castro's Cuba.

4003.author: Gore Vidal
4003.quote: Of all recent presidents, Clinton was expected to behave the most sensibly in economic matters. He understood how the economy works. But because he had used various dodges to stay out of the Vietnam War, he came to office ill at ease with the military.

4004.author: Gore Vidal
4004.quote: Europe began as the relatively empty, uncivilized Wild West of Asia; then the Western Hemisphere became the Wild West of Europe. Now the sun has set in our West and risen once more in the East.

4005.author: Gore Vidal
4005.quote: As the age of television progresses the Reagans will be the rule, not the exception. To be perfect for television is all a President has to be these days.

4006.author: Gore Vidal
4006.quote: The four most beautiful words in our common language: I told you so.

4007.author: Gore Vidal
4007.quote: I could be a lot happier. I could be the senator from Aerospace taking bribes, and be quite happy.

4008.author: Gore Vidal
4008.quote: Today's public figures can no longer write their own speeches or books, and there is some evidence that they can't read them either.

4009.author: Gore Vidal
4009.quote: To a man, ornithologists are tall, slender, and bearded so that they can stand motionless for hours, imitating kindly trees, as they watch for birds.

4010.author: Gore Vidal
4010.quote: While campaigning, I got to know many high-school teachers, and let me say that the good ones are the unsung heroes of our society, and the bad ones are the gravediggers.

4011.author: Gore Vidal
4011.quote: Anybody who is stupid enough to want to be remembered deserves to be forgotten right now.

4012.author: Gore Vidal
4012.quote: Until very recently, the artist was a magician who did his magic in public view but kept himself and his effects a matter of mystery.

4013.author: Gore Vidal
4013.quote: By the end of World War II, we were the most powerful and least damaged of the great nations. We also had most of the money. America's hegemony lasted exactly five years.

4014.author: Gore Vidal
4014.quote: To get people to do needed things is the perennial hard task of government, not to mention of religion and philosophy.

4015.author: Gore Vidal
4015.quote: For every Scott Fitzgerald concerned with the precise word and the selection of relevant incident, there are a hundred American writers, many well-regarded, who appear to believe that one word is just as good as another and that everything which occurs to them is worth putting down.

4016.author: Gore Vidal
4016.quote: Write something, even if it's just a suicide note.

4017.author: Groucho Marx
4017.quote: Outside of a dog, a book is a man's best friend. Inside of a dog it's too dark to read.

4018.author: Groucho Marx
4018.quote: The secret of life is honesty and fair dealing. If you can fake that, you've got it made.

4019.author: Groucho Marx
4019.quote: Man does not control his own fate. The women in his life do that for him.

4020.author: Groucho Marx
4020.quote: Behind every successful man is a woman, behind her is his wife.

4021.author: Groucho Marx
4021.quote: I have had a perfectly wonderful evening, but this wasn't it.

4022.author: Groucho Marx
4022.quote: A black cat crossing your path signifies that the animal is going somewhere.

4023.author: Groucho Marx
4023.quote: A hospital bed is a parked taxi with the meter running.

4024.author: Groucho Marx
4024.quote: Politics is the art of looking for trouble, finding it everywhere, diagnosing it incorrectly and applying the wrong remedies.

4025.author: Groucho Marx
4025.quote: I, not events, have the power to make me happy or unhappy today. I can choose which it shall be. Yesterday is dead, tomorrow hasn't arrived yet. I have just one day, today, and I'm going to be happy in it.

4026.author: Groucho Marx
4026.quote: No man goes before his time - unless the boss leaves early.

4027.author: Groucho Marx
4027.quote: I refuse to join any club that would have me as a member.

4028.author: Groucho Marx
4028.quote: It isn't necessary to have relatives in Kansas City in order to be unhappy.

4029.author: Groucho Marx
4029.quote: Getting older is no problem. You just have to live long enough.

4030.author: Groucho Marx
4030.quote: Those are my principles, and if you don't like them... well, I have others.

4031.author: Groucho Marx
4031.quote: Anyone who says he can see through women is missing a lot.

4032.author: Groucho Marx
4032.quote: One morning I shot an elephant in my pajamas. How he got into my pajamas I'll never know.

4033.author: Groucho Marx
4033.quote: I never forget a face, but in your case I'll be glad to make an exception.

4034.author: Groucho Marx
4034.quote: I remember the first time I had sex - I kept the receipt.

4035.author: Groucho Marx
4035.quote: I intend to live forever, or die trying.

4036.author: Groucho Marx
4036.quote: I've had a perfectly wonderful evening. But this wasn't it.

4037.author: Groucho Marx
4037.quote: Quote me as saying I was mis-quoted.

4038.author: Groucho Marx
4038.quote: Next time I see you, remind me not to talk to you.

4040.author: Groucho Marx
4040.quote: A child of five would understand this. Send someone to fetch a child of five.

4041.author: Groucho Marx
4041.quote: Alimony is like buying hay for a dead horse.

4042.author: Groucho Marx
4042.quote: I don't care to belong to a club that accepts people like me as members.

4043.author: H. G. Wells
4043.quote: If you fell down yesterday, stand up today.

4044.author: H. G. Wells
4044.quote: Affliction comes to us, not to make us sad but sober; not to make us sorry but wise.

4045.author: H. G. Wells
4045.quote: Beauty is in the heart of the beholder.

4046.author: H. G. Wells
4046.quote: What really matters is what you do with what you have.

4048.author: H. G. Wells
4048.quote: The New Deal is plainly an attempt to achieve a working socialism and avert a social collapse in America; it is extraordinarily parallel to the successive 'policies' and 'Plans' of the Russian experiment. Americans shirk the word 'socialism', but what else can one call it?

4049.author: H. G. Wells
4049.quote: If we don't end war, war will end us.

4050.author: H. G. Wells
4050.quote: The past is the beginning of the beginning and all that is and has been is but the twilight of the dawn.

4051.author: H. G. Wells
4051.quote: Every time I see an adult on a bicycle, I no longer despair for the future of the human race.

4052.author: H. G. Wells
4052.quote: The crisis of today is the joke of tomorrow.

4053.author: H. G. Wells
4053.quote: The only true measure of success is the ratio between what we might have done and what we might have been on the one hand, and the thing we have made and the things we have made of ourselves on the other.

4054.author: H. G. Wells
4054.quote: Moral indignation is jealousy with a halo.

4055.author: H. G. Wells
4055.quote: Adapt or perish, now as ever, is nature's inexorable imperative.

4056.author: H. G. Wells
4056.quote: The path of least resistance is the path of the loser.

4058.author: H. G. Wells
4058.quote: I must confess that my imagination refuses to see any sort of submarine doing anything but suffocating its crew and floundering at sea.

4059.author: H. G. Wells
4059.quote: Man is the unnatural animal, the rebel child of nature, and more and more does he turn himself against the harsh and fitful hand that reared him.

4060.author: H. G. Wells
4060.quote: Leaders should lead as far as they can and then vanish. Their ashes should not choke the fire they have lit.

4061.author: H. G. Wells
4061.quote: Human history becomes more and more a race between education and catastrophe.

4062.author: H. G. Wells
4062.quote: We are living in 1937, and our universities, I suggest, are not half-way out of the fifteenth century. We have made hardly any changes in our conception of university organization, education, graduation, for a century - for several centuries.

4063.author: H. G. Wells
4063.quote: One of the darkest evils of our world is surely the unteachable wildness of the Good.

4064.author: H. G. Wells
4064.quote: Once the command of the air is obtained by one of the contending armies, the war becomes a conflict between a seeing host and one that is blind.

4065.author: H. G. Wells
4065.quote: While there is a chance of the world getting through its troubles, I hold that a reasonable man has to behave as though he were sure of it. If at the end your cheerfulness in not justified, at any rate you will have been cheerful.

4066.author: H. G. Wells
4066.quote: The doctrine of the Kingdom of Heaven, which was the main teaching of Jesus, is certainly one of the most revolutionary doctrines that ever stirred and changed human thought.

4067.author: H. G. Wells
4067.quote: Some people bear three kinds of trouble - the ones they've had, the ones they have, and the ones they expect to have.

4068.author: H. G. Wells
4068.quote: The uglier a man's legs are, the better he plays golf - it's almost a law.

4069.author: H. L. Mencken
4069.quote: In war the heroes always outnumber the soldiers ten to one.

4070.author: H. L. Mencken
4070.quote: Democracy is the art and science of running the circus from the monkey cage.

4071.author: H. L. Mencken
4071.quote: On some great and glorious day the plain folks of the land will reach their heart's desire at last, and the White House will be adorned by a downright moron.

4072.author: H. L. Mencken
4072.quote: Legend: A lie that has attained the dignity of age.

4073.author: H. L. Mencken
4073.quote: Every election is a sort of advance auction sale of stolen goods.

4074.author: H. L. Mencken
4074.quote: The whole aim of practical politics is to keep the populace alarmed (and hence clamorous to be led to safety) by menacing it with an endless series of hobgoblins, all of them imaginary.

4075.author: H. L. Mencken
4075.quote: For every complex problem there is an answer that is clear, simple, and wrong.

4076.author: H. L. Mencken
4076.quote: Democracy is a pathetic belief in the collective wisdom of individual ignorance.

4077.author: H. L. Mencken
4077.quote: Every decent man is ashamed of the government he lives under.

4078.author: H. L. Mencken
4078.quote: In this world of sin and sorrow there is always something to be thankful for; as for me, I rejoice that I am not a Republican.

4079.author: H. L. Mencken
4079.quote: Every normal man must be tempted, at times, to spit on his hands, hoist the black flag, and begin slitting throats.

4080.author: H. L. Mencken
4080.quote: A national political campaign is better than the best circus ever heard of, with a mass baptism and a couple of hangings thrown in.

4081.author: H. L. Mencken
4081.quote: A newspaper is a device for making the ignorant more ignorant and the crazy crazier.

4082.author: H. L. Mencken
4082.quote: The urge to save humanity is almost always a false front for the urge to rule.

4083.author: H. L. Mencken
4083.quote: Puritanism. The haunting fear that someone, somewhere, may be happy.

4084.author: H. L. Mencken
4084.quote: I never smoked a cigarette until I was nine.

4085.author: H. L. Mencken
4085.quote: Democracy is the theory that the common people know what they want, and deserve to get it good and hard.

4086.author: H. L. Mencken
4086.quote: A judge is a law student who marks his own examination papers.

4087.author: H. L. Mencken
4087.quote: Conscience is a mother-in-law whose visit never ends.

4088.author: H. L. Mencken
4088.quote: A professor must have a theory as a dog must have fleas.

4089.author: H. L. Mencken
4089.quote: I believe that all government is evil, and that trying to improve it is largely a waste of time.

4090.author: H. L. Mencken
4090.quote: Giving every man a vote has no more made men wise and free than Christianity has made them good.

4091.author: H. L. Mencken
4091.quote: The most dangerous man to any government is the man who is able to think things out... without regard to the prevailing superstitions and taboos. Almost inevitably he comes to the conclusion that the government he lives under is dishonest, insane, intolerable.

4092.author: H. L. Mencken
4092.quote: Immorality: the morality of those who are having a better time.

4093.author: H. L. Mencken
4093.quote: No one in this world, so far as I know - and I have searched the records for years, and employed agents to help me - has ever lost money by underestimating the intelligence of the great masses of the plain people.

4094.author: H. L. Mencken
4094.quote: Strike an average between what a woman thinks of her husband a month before she marries him and what she thinks of him a year afterward, and you will have the truth about him.

4095.author: H. P. Lovecraft
4095.quote: The oldest and strongest emotion of mankind is fear, and the oldest and strongest kind of fear is fear of the unknown.

4096.author: H. P. Lovecraft
4096.quote: Unhappy is he to whom the memories of childhood bring only fear and sadness.

4097.author: H. P. Lovecraft
4097.quote: Cats are the runes of beauty, invincibility, wonder, pride, freedom, coldness, self-sufficiency, and dainty individuality - the qualities of sensitive, enlightened, mentally developed, pagan, cynical, poetic, philosophic, dispassionate, reserved, independent, Nietzschean, unbroken, civilised, master-class men.

4098.author: H. P. Lovecraft
4098.quote: It is absolutely necessary, for the peace and safety of mankind, that some of earth's dark, dead corners and unplumbed depths be let alone; lest sleeping abnormalities wake to resurgent life, and blasphemously surviving nightmares squirm and splash out of their black lairs to newer and wider conquests.

4099.author: H. P. Lovecraft
4099.quote: We live on a placid island of ignorance in the midst of black seas of infinity, and it was not meant that we should voyage far.

4100.author: H. P. Lovecraft
4100.quote: It is a mistake to fancy that horror is associated inextricably with darkness, silence, and solitude.

4101.author: H. P. Lovecraft
4101.quote: The process of delving into the black abyss is to me the keenest form of fascination.

4102.author: H. P. Lovecraft
4102.quote: The world is indeed comic, but the joke is on mankind.

4103.author: H. P. Lovecraft
4103.quote: If religion were true, its followers would not try to bludgeon their young into an artificial conformity; but would merely insist on their unbending quest for truth, irrespective of artificial backgrounds or practical consequences.

4104.author: H. P. Lovecraft
4104.quote: Fear is our deepest and strongest emotion, and the one which best lends itself to the creation of nature-defying illusions.

4105.author: H. P. Lovecraft
4105.quote: But more wonderful than the lore of old men and the lore of books is the secret lore of ocean.

4106.author: H. P. Lovecraft
4106.quote: Toil without song is like a weary journey without an end.

4107.author: H. P. Lovecraft
4107.quote: We must realise that man's nature will remain the same so long as he remains man; that civilisation is but a slight coverlet beneath which the dominant beast sleeps lightly and ever ready to awake. To preserve civilisation, we must deal scientifically with the brute element, using only genuine biological principles.

4108.author: H. P. Lovecraft
4108.quote: Plots may be simple or complex, but suspense, and climactic progress from one incident to another, are essential. Every incident in a fictional work should have some bearing on the climax or denouement, and any denouement which is not the inevitable result of the preceding incidents is awkward and unliterary.

4109.author: H. P. Lovecraft
4109.quote: The end of a story must be stronger rather than weaker than the beginning, since it is the end which contains the denouement or culmination and which will leave the strongest impression upon the reader.

4110.author: H. P. Lovecraft
4110.quote: Blue, green, grey, white, or black; smooth, ruffled, or mountainous; that ocean is not silent.

4111.author: H. P. Lovecraft
4111.quote: We shall see that at which dogs howl in the dark, and that at which cats prick up their ears after midnight.

4112.author: H. P. Lovecraft
